Work at winning companies over better titles - better to be an IC PM at Google than VP Product at Yahoo; winners attract talent, create unfair brand halo, and teach you what excellence looks like

Hire your first PM at 8-10 engineers by converting an internal engineer/analyst/designer - external PMs often get rejected like foreign organs; first PM needs founder and eng team trust to be the liaison

Hire lieutenants from best-in-class companies, not the heads - find companies excellent at the function you need, map their org chart on LinkedIn, and recruit the person reporting to the leader (Square's payments team got raided this way)

Avoid feature factories by empowering teams with problems not features - biggest founder mistake is becoming too tactical and telling engineers what to build instead of presenting problems and letting teams brainstorm solutions

contrarian_candidates.why: Challenges conventional wisdom of chasing titles and seniority - argues being an IC at a winning company beats being VP at a mediocre one
Strongly opposes giving director/VP titles early despite standard startup practice of using titles to attract talent
Argues sins of omission (passing on investments) are worse than sins of commission (losing money) - contrarian to VC conventional wisdom

episodes.episode_title: How to get press for your product | Jason Feifer (editor in chief of Entrepreneur magazine)

quotes.text: We run a very different kind of business. We are focused on efficiency, we're not focused on growth. We don't have any salespeople. We don't have 15 different versions of Basecamp. We're not after enterprise, so we don't have the enormous support costs and enormous support infrastructure required to service customers like that. Nobody can pay us more than 300 bucks. What that allows us to do is to just build one product, do a really nice job, keep it tight, and simple, and clear, and not have the complexity that comes with trying to service and satisfy so many different kinds of companies at different price levels with different price points and different expectations.
quotes.context: Explaining why 37signals has 75 employees while competitors have 1000-3000 employees with similar customer counts

quotes.text: We build products with two people at a time. So every feature we work on in Basecamp, or HEY, or whatever we're building is two people, one programmer, one designer, and they have a maximum of six weeks to deliver the feature that they're working on. Most of them are usually a couple of weeks, but they have a maximum of six weeks. So we don't get stuck in these big huge projects, with meetings with 18 people, and slow decision-making, and indecision, and complexity, and all the things that come with trying to do too many things for too many people.
quotes.context: Describing 37signals' Shape Up methodology for product development

quotes.text: We think that constraints, simplicity, small teams actually are where it's at, and keep us honest, and allow us to do great work for our customer base that we know, small businesses, very tight companies like ours. If you gave me 1,000 people, I wouldn't know what to do with them. We would fall apart. If you gave me 500 people, I wouldn't know what to do with them. We would fall apart. We would be a worse off company with 500 people. I'd be completely lost.
quotes.context: Discussing why staying small is intentional, not just a stepping stone

quotes.text: For me, it's really about, would I want to do this again? If the answer is, 'Yeah, that was enjoyable. I enjoyed that. That was worthwhile. I'm glad I did that. I'd like to do that again,' then it was successful. On the business side of things, we have to be profitable. It's in total, collectively, are we making more money than we spend? That's the only thing we ultimately look at. We don't have financial goals. We don't have OKRs or KPIs. I don't have revenue targets. I don't have growth targets. It's just, at the end, 'Did we make more than we spend? We did. Then the things we did this year were worth it.'
quotes.context: Defining what success means at 37signals - enjoyment over metrics

quotes.text: This is my day job. I want to create the company that I want to work at, and I want to keep doing this job for as long as I can. As long as I'm useful, I'm good at it, I enjoy it, I want to keep doing that. To get in bed with an investment that would say, 'In five years you have to stop doing what you're doing, you're going to get a big paycheck maybe, but you got to stop doing what you're doing because we're going to sell this business,' that just has no appeal to me at all. I'd rather just keep doing the thing that I'm enjoying doing, as long as I can continue to make it work.
quotes.context: Discussing infinite games and why raising venture capital doesn't align with his goals

quotes.text: There's only a few slots for a few companies like that at any one time. Meanwhile, there are hundreds or thousands of slots for other kinds of companies to make it if they don't go for the moon. My interest is optionality. If I could land in 135 different positions and have a sustainable business, that's great. Versus saying there's only one way I'm going to be successful or happy. Those odds aren't really in anyone's favor.
quotes.context: Explaining why the venture-backed unicorn path is not the only path to success

quotes.text: We instead have appetites. And our appetite for any individual feature is no more than six weeks. Essentially that's our budget we're willing to spend. I'm only willing to spend six weeks on any feature. So we have to figure out the simplest, most effective version of that to get that done within six weeks and get it done by two people. Work expands to fill the time available. So for us it's about appetite.
quotes.context: Explaining the Shape Up methodology's concept of appetites vs estimates

quotes.text: Promises are the downfall of every business. Every time we've made a promise to get something out in a certain period of time and we kind of inevitably seem to miss it, it's funny how it's almost like it would've been out in time, but the fact that we'd promised it made it not deliver in time. There's some strange thing that happens when you promise things. So we've learned to not promise anything. The worst promise is by the end of the year. That's the one promise you got to be very careful of, because it's so easy to make. There's nothing easier than promising work later.
quotes.context: Discussing why they don't make promises about delivery dates

quotes.text: I think everything's a judgment call. Yeah, data can play a part. All sorts of things can play a part, but unless you're letting a machine make the decision, that's purely rational. If you're asking a human to make it's a judgment call. They're bringing to bear thousands of things they know and don't know about that influence them about this particular decision. When companies hire executives, what are they looking for? They typically go judgment and experience. They're not like they can read an Excel spreadsheet. They're looking for judgment and experience, which is a very amorphous thing.
quotes.context: Defending gut-driven decision making over data-driven approaches

quotes.text: Give your intuition credit. Give your gut credit. It's absorbed everything. And plus the things that you don't know it absorbed that are valuable. We ask people, what do you think? We might say, what do you know? But we also say, what do you think more often. We talk about how does this feel? How does this screen feel? How does this flow feel? How does this feature feel? Because human beings feel. While we have a logical side to us and a rational side to us, we're primarily feeling creatures.
quotes.context: Encouraging teams to trust their instincts and feelings in product decisions

quotes.text: I didn't have any of this planned out. I didn't decide I wanted to be like this or like that. I just figure out what works and keep doing that until it doesn't. And then, maybe we do something else. We're very much an in-the-now company, making it up as we go. I'm not on a path. I can't see the path. I don't know where I'm going, and I'm perfectly comfortable with that. I think the further out you plan, the less you know about the decisions you're making. And by the time you get there, you're probably going to be wrong, or you're going to want to do something else.
quotes.context: Explaining why they don't do long-term planning and embrace uncertainty

quotes.text: The reason I think it's great for entrepreneurs to start bootstrapping is because they just have more practice making money. They get better and better and better at the fundamental skill you need to have ultimately to run a successful business, which is to make money. Getting good at spending money is not a valuable skill as getting good at making money. You need constraints. When you have just loads of money, you basically have very few constraints. That's what tends to lead to slop.
quotes.context: Explaining why bootstrapping teaches better business fundamentals than venture capital

takeaways: Constraints and small teams breed better work than unlimited resources - staying small is a destination, not just a stepping stone
Success means wanting to do it again, not hitting arbitrary metrics - profitable enjoyment over growth targets and OKRs
Appetites (fixed time budgets) beat estimates - give features 6 weeks max, forcing simplicity and preventing endless projects
Bootstrapping teaches the fundamental skill of making money through practice and constraints, while VC money teaches spending
Trust gut and intuition in decisions - executives hire for judgment and experience, not Excel-reading ability

contrarian_candidates.why: Rejects OKRs, revenue targets, and growth metrics entirely - success is just 'would I do this again?'
Claims promises are the downfall of every business - directly challenges roadmap/commitment culture
Everything is a judgment call, not data-driven - executives hired for judgment, not Excel skills

episodes.episode_title: From managing people to managing AI: The leadership skills everyone needs now | Julie Zhuo

quotes.text: Management is just about having an outcome. You have a north star, you have a vision, and you're just trying to figure out how to use the resources that you have to get that thing done. Used to be people, but now it's basically models and different models have different strengths. You have to assemble the Avengers so that you can use the right tools for the right purposes.
quotes.context: Explaining how management principles apply directly to working with AI agents and models

quotes.text: Defining the goal and defining the outcome and being really, really crystal clear on what does success look like is the first skill. Different people may have different pictures of what success looks like. How do we get even more specific so that we know without question whether we've hit it or not. This is actually a really, really difficult problem.
quotes.context: Explaining why clarity of outcomes is the most important skill for working with AI and teams

quotes.text: AI allows me to do many of those jobs myself. Now, I'm not going to do them at the PhD or the highest 1%, 10% level, but if I was at the zero or 10th percentile, it can certainly get me even today very quickly up to the 60th, 70th. We need to dissolve the boundaries of these traditional roles. Call ourselves builders. I'd love for us to get to the world where that's the title.
quotes.context: Describing how AI empowers individuals to transcend traditional role boundaries

quotes.text: I don't actually think a lot of the fast-growing companies are using data well at this point. Traditionally things just didn't grow that fast. These companies are totally getting by on just good instincts and good vibes. But what always happens is eventually things stop growing. Growth does not happen forever. And usually when growth stops, that's when you start to see the power of good observability.
quotes.context: Contrarian take on how fast-growing AI companies succeed initially without data infrastructure

quotes.text: What you really want is you want to diagnose with data and treat with design. Data is not a tool that's going to tell you what you should build or what the solution is. But it can tell you if you have a problem and where that problem or opportunity might be. You still need to go back and undergo a very creative process to figure out what's the best way to solve that.
quotes.context: Sharing the perfect framework for balancing data and design that she and her co-founder use

quotes.text: Management is really about this idea of be sturdy while being flexible. I think about this metaphor a lot of the willow tree. The willow tree is a very sturdy tree. It can survive a lot of storms, disasters, et cetera, but it's also very flexible. The branches are very, very flexible, and that's in some ways what allows it to be very sturdy.
quotes.context: Describing the essential balance managers need in times of rapid change and uncertainty

quotes.text: I'm a big believer that every strength is its own weakness, and every weakness is a strength. There's no such thing as you're going to somehow get every dimension to be 100%. We can kind of look at you in infinite dimensions. Each of our profiles is very unique, it's like a fingerprint. None of these dimensions are you entirely. Somebody can give you feedback or you can have room to improve, and that's not who you are.
quotes.context: Introducing the dimensionality framework for self-awareness and managing personal development

quotes.text: Feedback is essentially trying to put your hypotheses and test them against reality. I'm going to ask you for feedback and you're going to give me a gift. It'll be a gift of reflecting something back of what you see that I can't see. Just like if I have a leaf in the back of my head, I can't see that. That is what feedback is. It is essentially reflection back.
quotes.context: Reframing feedback as a gift that helps calibrate our self-perception to reality

quotes.text: It's very difficult for managers to convey purpose if you don't have conviction yourself. Watching your conviction is really important. Sometimes what new managers don't pay attention to enough is what is their true belief. If you don't really believe in what you're doing or you're just parroting the thing that got passed through the organization, it's very hard to be effective or hold that vision and purpose.
quotes.context: Explaining why managers must develop genuine conviction rather than just executing orders

quotes.text: I think if you start thinking adversarially like 'my getting better outcomes has to come at the expense of somebody else losing something,' it's very difficult to be successful. If you say, 'Look, actually, my job is to figure out how to create win-wins,' a lot of things get easier. That has to be a collaboration. If it's not win-win and you could be wrong, that would actually be great information because then maybe we can go back and find a way to make it win-win.
quotes.context: Describing win-win thinking as fundamental to effective management and difficult conversations

quotes.text: I believe that there's infinity in every direction. If my kids say something like going outside is boring or taking a walk is boring, my general response will be, 'Well, it's because you're not seeing the infinity that's in that direction.' Even something really mundane like staring at a blank wall, you can make that actually deeply, deeply interesting if you can find the thing that is deep, and rich, and infinite in that direction.
quotes.context: Sharing her contrarian philosophical worldview that applies to work and life

quotes.text: Emotional regulation is still really, really important. AI makes things so much more comfortable. Technology makes things a lot easier, but you can shortcut a lot of things. How do we actually still learn to sit with what is our true biology that's not changing? True freedom is you can pick the things that are hard and you can feel pride in becoming the thing that you want to be. Don't think about it as a shortcut tool.
quotes.context: Explaining what she teaches her kids about emotional skills in an AI-powered future

takeaways: Managing AI agents requires the same skills as managing people - define clear outcomes, understand each agent's strengths like assembling the Avengers, and create the right processes; the fundamentals haven't changed

Diagnose with data, treat with design - data tells you if you have a problem and where it is, but you still need creative design thinking to figure out the solution; they're complementary tools not opposites
Be like the willow tree in times of change - sturdy enough to survive storms but flexible enough to bend; managers must balance certainty and adaptability as AI accelerates the rate of change

Use the dimensionality framework for self-awareness - every human has infinite dimensions of strengths and weaknesses; feedback on one dimension doesn't threaten your identity, and every strength has a corresponding weakness

Managers need genuine conviction not just orders - if you don't truly believe in what you're doing, you're just parroting and won't be effective at holding the vision; work through disagreements to find real belief or test assumptions

contrarian_candidates.why: Challenges the narrative that fast-growing AI companies are data-driven - argues they're succeeding on vibes and instincts, data becomes important only when growth stops
Rejects the self-improvement narrative of eliminating weaknesses - argues every strength IS a weakness and vice versa, you can't max out every dimension
Warns against using AI as shortcuts - while most focus on AI's productivity gains, Julie argues emotional regulation and choosing hard things is more important for human fulfillment

episodes.episode_title: Product management theater | Marty Cagan (Silicon Valley Product Group)

quotes.text: There is no question that a lot of companies overhired during the pandemic. I go into some companies and honestly I can't believe all the ridiculous roles that they have, agile coaches and product owners and product ops and business analysts. They're dramatically overpaid for the value they provide. Because it's a project management role.

Too many people in our industry view themselves as a victim of their company, like they're stuck in a feature team and there's nothing they can do about it other than quit. I think that's not true. There is so much they can do.

On a feature team, you're basically given a roadmap of output. Their features are projects. You're being asked to design, build, test, deploy that feature. It is a lot easier to deliver output than it is to deliver outcomes. A product team, instead of being given that roadmap of features, they're given problems to solve.

Strong product companies understand it's all about outcomes. You just don't get points for shipping, you get points for delivering the value. It's about time to money more than time to market. We know how to do time to market. The harder part is time to money.

You need this person who understands the customers and understands the business deeply. That's where the product manager role came from. You need a different set of skills that your engineers and your designers almost never have. Those are very different skillsets.

On a real empowered product team, product manager is a creator, not a facilitator. I always cringe when somebody tells me, oh, my job is to say why? And I'm like, 'Well, what do you do for the rest of the week besides the 10 minutes it takes you to say why?' It's ridiculous.

I was not allowed to take the product manager role until I had visited 30 customers in person, 15 in the US, 15 in Europe. Those 30 customers changed my life because I thought I knew our customers and I really didn't.

You're supposed to be the expert on the data. How is our product being used? How is that usage changing over time? Another big one is you are the person on the team that represents the compliance issues, the sales issues, the marketing issues, the financial cost issues, the monetization issues, go to market in general. This is all the product manager.

Most product management advice you find online, probably 90% of the content out there is from the feature team world or worse. Unless they get really lucky or they happen to have a manager that is guiding them in a good direction, it just propagates.

Product leaders do product strategy. Product teams don't do product strategy. That is the job, is to make these strategic decisions, the focus decisions, the bets you're going to place. Then you give those bets to the teams and you really do give them latitude to figure it out.

Empowerment does not mean you set up this product team and they go decide what to work on. That would just be anarchy. Empowerment means the leaders do their job, come up with the bets, and then the teams are able to figure out the best way to solve those problems.

If you are fundamentally a backlog administrator, good luck protecting that because already people are doing that with AI. That is not a good job prospect. For an empowered product manager, if your responsibility is value and viability, that's the real challenge left.

takeaways: Product managers must be creators solving real problems, not facilitators managing backlogs - that's theater, not real PM work
Feature teams get roadmaps of output to ship; empowered product teams get problems to solve and are measured on outcomes
Strong PMs deeply understand customers (30+ visits), data (usage patterns), and business viability (legal, sales, monetization)
Most online PM advice (90%) comes from feature team environments and propagates the wrong model of product management
Empowerment means leaders set strategy and bets, teams figure out how to solve - not anarchy where teams pick their own problems

episodes.episode_title: Driving alignment within teams, work-life balance, and the changing PM landscape | Nikita Miller

quotes.text: I looked on the App Store and the number one app in the United States was an app called Sarahah, but the entire app was in Arabic. Like the strongest signal that you could ever have that people want something. The way you should search for product ideas is this concept of latent demand where people are trying to obtain a particular value and going through a very distortive process.
quotes.context: Describing how he discovered the opportunity for tbh by observing an Arabic app being #1 in US

quotes.text: We built 15 apps over four or five years. One took us about a year at first, then our last one took us about two weeks. The most important thing I instruct teams to do is develop a reproducible testing process. That will influence the probability of your success more than anything. It's so unpredictable whether a consumer product idea will work - if you focus on your process for taking many shots at bat, that's what actually reduces the risk.
quotes.context: Explaining the importance of iteration speed and systematic testing over individual ideas

quotes.text: Every tap on a mobile app is a miracle for you as a product developer because users will turn and bounce to their next app very quickly. If you actually sit behind someone and watch them use their phone, they switch between apps at a pretty high frequency. Every tap that you get, every single one is so scarce that you should be optimizing everything.
quotes.context: Describing the shift from web to mobile product thinking and design philosophy

quotes.text: When you're testing something, test the best possible version of what that could be, whether it takes manual work or something that is never going to scale. You want to eliminate all those potentially confounding variables so you can know immediately whether something's working or not. You never want to walk away from an experiment and say 'Well, maybe the execution was bad.'
quotes.context: Explaining why they manually seeded entire schools to test apps properly

quotes.text: When people ask 'What's the benchmark for product-market fit?' this founder Roger Dickey told me: 'If your product's working, you'll know. And if there's any uncertainty, it's not working.' It really is a binary when it comes to consumer products. People are going to be fighting to get into it. Our metric was hourly actives per day, not daily active users.
quotes.context: Describing what true product-market fit feels like for consumer apps

quotes.text: The thing that is hard to really understand for first-time founders that hit breakout success is how draining it is, because everything breaks. Everything you built needs to be substituted almost every three days. Our first customer support system broke after three days. The next one broke seven days later. It is absolute chaos to keep the thing online as it scales up.
quotes.context: Describing the reality of hypergrowth with tbh going viral

quotes.text: For every social app I've built, the number of invitations sent per user drops 20% for every additional year of age from 13 to 18. If you build for adults, expect to acquire every user with ads. If you're targeting older cohorts, you're going to have to raise huge venture capital to finance that user acquisition pipeline.
quotes.context: Explaining why teens are the optimal target for viral social apps

quotes.text: People download apps to make or save money (WhatsApp - free texting), to find a mate (Tinder, Snapchat - find love), or to unplug from reality (Netflix, Fortnite). Putting that in a framing document and the particular nuanced reason why people are going to adopt is difficult when you're presenting to seasoned professionals inside a large company.
quotes.context: Explaining his framework for why people download apps and why big companies struggle with zero-to-one

quotes.text: Large companies take 12 to 24 months to respond to competitive threats. An app starts charting, a PM makes a post, market research does a study, it floats around for months, they put together a framing deck, goes through VP reviews, then development takes 6-12 months. It's hard to present something you have a hunch about - you need market evidence or it's not defensible.
quotes.context: Explaining why incumbents are slow to respond and why copying is the only defensible path inside big companies

quotes.text: As a product manager in a large tech company, there is very little product management that you do. You're actually not as involved in the product as I assumed. You're completely detached from the design process. There's a design vertical org that does all that and they don't really want you working on that. Products live and die in the pixels - that's on you.
quotes.context: Describing the disconnect between PM role and actual product development at Facebook

quotes.text: Put live chat customer support in your app 24 hours a day. It sounds insane - the whole point of tech is you don't need that. But users get this white glove experience, and it's the best vehicle for getting feedback and doing user research because users will literally tell you the problem they're having. Our support rep would paste interesting feedback into Slack and we'd turn it into features.
quotes.context: Sharing tactical advice on eliminating confounding variables during product testing

quotes.text: At the peak of tbh, we were getting 360,000 installs per day. I looked at our numbers and I'm like 'We will be number one in the United States in six days.' Then I looked at our Amazon bill - $120,000. Our bank account said $150,000. I quickly had to put together a funding round. We geofenced the app because we needed to scale our servers and control growth.
quotes.context: Describing the chaos of tbh's viral growth and strategic decision to geofence to control it

takeaways: Search for latent demand - find where people are trying to obtain value through distortive processes (like an Arabic app being #1 in US) and crystallize what they actually want into a clean product experience

Build a reproducible testing process over perfect ideas - consumer product success is unpredictable, so systematic iteration (15 apps over 5 years, 1 year  2 weeks) reduces risk more than any single brilliant idea

Test the ideal version with manual work - eliminate confounding variables by manually seeding entire schools, providing 24/7 live chat, doing unscalable things to know with certainty whether the product works

Viral social apps require teens (13-18) - invitations drop 20% per year of age, so targeting adults means buying every user with ads and needing massive VC funding for acquisition instead of organic growth
Hypergrowth is absolute chaos - when you hit product-market fit, everything breaks every 3 days, you need ruthless prioritization, and you may need to geofence growth just to keep things online

contrarian_candidates.why: Argues process over ideas - most founders fixate on the perfect idea, but Nikita built 15 apps to develop systematic testing, contradicting 'visionary founder' narrative
Challenges conventional wisdom of building for profitable adult markets - argues teens are the ONLY viable target for viral social apps despite having zero money
Advocates for unscalable 24/7 live chat in apps - completely opposite to standard 'automated, self-serve' SaaS wisdom that dominates Silicon Valley thinking

quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.text: There is no such thing as a truly viral product. Even Facebook in its heyday had a viral factor of about 0.7. What I mean is, no app has sustained a viral factor of greater than one for any real period of time. The true secret behind virality is word of mouth. It is the virality you can't measure that isn't a mechanic that isn't in a feature. It is when one user spontaneously tells another user about your product.

quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.text: The Switch log. It's born out of the observation that your calendar says what you thought you were going to do, but it's really only your trail of work that describes what you actually did. What if I just did whatever the heck I wanted? Every single time I change task I just Slack DM'd my EA and said, 'TS:,' and then a few words for the task I was doing.

quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.text: I looked at all of the major font families, and honestly none of them was what I would call truly excellent. I was looking for a font that was in and of itself gorgeous, that could convey a message of any kind without overpowering the sentiment, that made reading speed and comprehension really fast, and that made email addresses themselves look great.

quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.text: Email is mission-critical. It's not something where you can simply launch with a half-baked product. When you have mission-critical products like email where you are interfacing with customers, with candidates, with investors, it turns out to really matter. That's why you can't just launch with a half-baked product.

quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.text: You have to pick something. The most well-known brands have stood for one clear thing, they have a clear position. So in order for Superhuman to be memorable, I believed that we needed to occupy a clear position that was unique and which was available and which reinforced our product strategy. That's how speed became our position.

quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.text: At peak we had about 20 people doing manual onboarding. What we found is two things. Number one, the user metrics are excellent for things like engagement, retention, product market fit score, MPS, virality. And number two, in a world where you can easily and quickly raise funding, you can actually use dollars to avoid building a first-time user experience and instead focus all of your engineers on finding product market fit.

quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.text: You can measure product market fit. You can optimize product market fit. You can systematically, even numerically increase product market fit. And you can even have an algorithm write your roadmap for you, and that is a roadmap that is guaranteed to increase product market fit.

quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.text: To get to product market fit, you have to deliberately not act on the feedback of many of your early users. You're listening to people intensely and building what people want. But it can't be all people. The question becomes, how do you listen to them? And then even of what they say, what do you pay attention to and what don't you?

quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.text: We should make business software like we make games, because when we make products like we make games, people find them fun. They tell their friends, they fall in love with them. It's another way of backing into word of mouth. It's not gamification, that doesn't work. Game design works, but game design is not gamification.

quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.text: Make fun toys and then combine those into games. The best games are constructed out of toys. Why? Because then they are fun on both levels, the toy and the game itself. Think about the features of your product. Do those features indulge playful exploration? Are they fun even without a goal? Do they elicit moments of pleasant surprise?

quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.text: SDR - Single Decisive Reason. For important decisions, you should be able to identify one reason that on its own supports the decision. All too often we rely on a collection of weak reasons to justify decisions. Multiple low quality reasons rarely add up to a high quality reason to do something.

takeaways: True virality comes from word of mouth, not viral mechanics - even Facebook never sustained a viral factor above 1.0. Focus on creating products people spontaneously tell others about.

Manual onboarding at scale is viable with the right economics - Superhuman had 20 people doing manual onboarding, which drove exceptional engagement metrics and let engineers focus on product-market fit instead of activation flows.

Product-market fit can be measured and systematically improved - focus on the 'somewhat disappointed' users for whom your main benefit resonates, not the people who already love you or those who don't care.
Game design (not gamification) makes products delightful - create 'toys' that are fun even without goals, that invite playful exploration and pleasant surprises, then combine them into games.
Single Decisive Reason (SDR) cuts through weak justifications - for any important decision, identify one reason that alone supports it. Multiple weak reasons rarely add up to a strong one.

episodes.episode_title: The art of product management | Shreyas Doshi (Stripe, Twitter, Google, Yahoo)

quotes.text: If you do a pre-mortem right, you will not have to do an ugly post-mortem. The genius is the initial prompt: imagine this project has failed six months from now. Now work backwards and ask what went wrong. It creates psychological safety for team members to talk about things they're concerned about without being negative.
quotes.context: Introducing the pre-mortem framework with tigers, paper tigers, and elephants

quotes.text: In a pre-mortem, bring up three things: a tiger (a threat that will actually kill us), a paper tiger (a seeming threat others worry about but you're not), and an elephant in the room that nobody is talking about. That shared vocabulary becomes powerful - in future meetings people started saying 'I have this tiger' and it became okay to bring those things up.
quotes.context: Explaining the specific structure of effective pre-mortems

quotes.text: All your tasks are not created equal. There are L tasks (leverage) where you put in effort and get 10X or 100X in return. N tasks (neutral) where you get what you put in. And O tasks (overhead) where you get back less than you put in. Most ambitious people treat each type the same way - and therein lies the problem.
quotes.context: Introducing the LNO framework for prioritizing PM time

quotes.text: The same activity can be an L, N, or O task depending on context. Filing a bug report can be leverage if it's a critical issue requiring detailed documentation, or overhead if it's minor and you're just being thorough. Taking notes can be leverage after a strategic CEO decision, or overhead after a routine sync.
quotes.context: Illustrating how the same activity requires different levels of effort based on strategic importance

quotes.text: Most execution problems that I encounter in high performing environments are actually not execution problems - they are either strategy problems or interpersonal problems or cultural problems. When you put on a bandaid and the bandaid falls off, it's probably not an execution issue.
quotes.context: Explaining why teams stay overwhelmed solving the same problems repeatedly

quotes.text: Two teams misaligned? It looks like an execution problem. But often it's because we don't know what the strategy is. We craft OKRs based on what makes sense, but they're not aligned because we lack clear strategy and priorities. All the review meetings in the world won't fix a strategy problem.
quotes.context: Illustrating how lack of strategy manifests as execution problems

quotes.text: In high leverage roles, stop doing work that simply provides positive ROI. Start focusing on work that minimizes opportunity cost. The problem with ROI mindset is you decrease the denominator by working on quick wins and low-hanging fruit. You fill your plate with quick wins and miss the upside by not focusing on optimal things.
quotes.context: Explaining the opportunity cost framework learned from observing Patrick Collison at Stripe

quotes.text: Opportunity cost is the value of the optimal option minus the value of the chosen option. When we reprogram ourselves to think in terms of opportunity cost, we're no longer thinking 'Is this a good use of my time?' Instead: 'Is this the best use of my time?' It's a subtle but profound shift.
quotes.context: Contrasting opportunity cost thinking with traditional ROI thinking

quotes.text: I learned from Google's 70-20-10: during planning, give teams allocation guidance. 60% on incrementals (high ROI features), 30% on big new initiatives (can't be five initiatives, probably one or two), 10% on stability and infrastructure. This gives people space to pursue the right things instead of filling everything with quick wins.
quotes.context: Sharing tactical guidance on portfolio allocation to enable opportunity cost thinking

quotes.text: High agency is finding a way to get what you want without waiting for conditions to be perfect or blaming circumstances. The PMs who surprised me in positive ways - exceeded their capabilities on paper - all had high agency: strong ownership, creative execution through challenges, and high resilience.
quotes.context: Describing the trait that differentiates high-impact PMs from those with unrealized potential

quotes.text: At Google I learned the power of thinking really big. There was this unwritten rule: if it's not going to generate more than $100 million in revenue, it's not worth talking about. They would regularly not pursue $100 million opportunities because they had access to billion dollar ones. That habit to ask 'can we make it 10X bigger?' got ingrained.
quotes.context: Describing Google's culture of thinking big and pursuing only massive opportunities

quotes.text: Jack Dorsey would just listen a lot more than you'd expect the CEO to listen. Then he would ask one vital question. We discussed a potential acquisition - went through all the intellectual arguments, strategic arguments, metrics arguments. Jack asked: 'How does this make our users love Twitter more?' Simple question. We never really talked about that. I didn't have a good answer.
quotes.context: Describing Jack Dorsey's leadership style and ability to ask penetrating questions

takeaways: Run pre-mortems with tigers, paper tigers, and elephants - imagine the project failed six months from now and work backwards to identify threats, creating psychological safety to discuss concerns without being 'negative'

Use the LNO framework to prioritize time - identify which tasks are Leverage (10-100X return), Neutral (1X return), or Overhead (<1X return), and treat them differently instead of applying equal effort to everything

Most execution problems are actually strategy or culture problems - when the same issues keep recurring despite bandaid fixes, look for missing strategy, cultural misalignment, or interpersonal friction as root causes

Minimize opportunity cost instead of maximizing ROI - stop asking 'is this good use of time?' and start asking 'is this the BEST use of time?' to avoid filling your roadmap with quick wins while missing transformative bets

High agency PMs exceed their on-paper potential through strong ownership, creative execution through challenges, and resilience - they find ways to achieve goals without waiting for perfect conditions or blaming circumstances

contrarian_candidates.why: Challenges conventional wisdom that execution problems need execution solutions - argues most are actually strategy/culture problems disguised as execution issues
Goes against ubiquitous ROI-maximization advice - argues that chasing positive ROI leads to quick wins addiction and missing transformative opportunities
Reveals Google's contrarian filter of ignoring $100M opportunities - most companies would celebrate such wins, but thinking bigger meant only pursuing billion-dollar bets

episodes.episode_title: Mental models for building products people love ft. Stewart Butterfield

quotes.text: We're on these narrow sidewalks in Vancouver when it starts raining. Most people with umbrellas wouldn't move them out of the way - the pokey bits are at eye level. Only one-third would tilt their umbrella. We said your failure to really exercise this courtesy and be empathic about other people's experience is an advantage that you can create.
quotes.context: The umbrella tilt story that became a core Slack value about product craftsmanship and empathy

quotes.text: Utility curves: first bit of effort produces no value, then there's a magic threshold where it produces enormous value, then continued investment doesn't pay off. We would investigate whether we were on the first shallow part of the curve, the second shallow part, or just coming up to it. This helped us decide whether something was worth it.
quotes.context: Explaining the utility curve S-curve framework for product investment decisions

quotes.text: It became an assumption that you should always be trying to remove friction. But the challenge is really comprehension. If your software stops me and asks me to make a decision and I don't really understand it, you make me feel stupid. Instead of reducing clicks or taps, focus on how can I make this simple? How do I prevent people from having to think?
quotes.context: Explaining why comprehension matters more than reducing friction or clicks

quotes.text: Have you exhausted the possibilities? Creating the distance so that you can make an intellectual rational decision rather than an emotional decision is essential. The reason I say you have to be coldly rational is because pivoting is fucking humiliating. You convinced so many people - investors, employees, press, users - and now you're admitting 'I was wrong. This didn't work.'
quotes.context: Explaining the emotional difficulty of pivoting after Glitch  Slack and Flickr pivots

quotes.text: This is 2014, the year Slack launched. MIT Technology Review asked if we were working to improve Slack. I said, 'I feel like what we have right now is just a giant piece of shit. It's terrible and we should be humiliated that we offer this to the public.' If you can't see almost limitless opportunities to improve, you shouldn't be designing the product.
quotes.context: Expressing divine discontent and high standards for Slack even after launch

quotes.text: We invented the magic link experience. Typing your password on your phone if you have any minimal threshold of password hygiene is a terrible experience. Capital H, lowercase Q, six, caret, period. So let's just have them enter email address, send them a link, and it automatically opens the app and authenticates them.
quotes.context: Describing Slack's early UX innovation that became an industry standard

quotes.text: We came up with the shouty rooster. When you @everyone, a little rooster pops up with sound waves and says 'This is going to cause a notification for 147 people in eight different time zones. Are you sure?' That worked amazingly - it dropped off the abuse. It also taught people how the product worked because they probably didn't think about the cost.
quotes.context: Example of delightful UX that shapes behavior and prevents spam

quotes.text: In the long run, the measure of our success will be the amount of value that we create for customers. You can put effort into demonstrating that you have created this value, but there's no substitute for actually having created it. I made everyone in the company repeat this as a chant at all hands.
quotes.context: The core philosophy that guided Slack's product development

quotes.text: The default advice for anyone is persevere - 'hang in there.' But I think you have to be coldly rational. Slack had an enormous advantage: we were working on it for several years without explicitly working on it, only doing features that were so irritating we couldn't stand it anymore. When I had exhausted every non-ridiculous long shot idea to make Glitch commercially successful, I decided to abandon it.
quotes.context: Explaining when to pivot vs persevere using the Glitch  Slack example

quotes.text: Don't Make Me Think. For two reasons: it's expensive to make a decision - you literally burn glucose, there's cognitive cost. But also there's an emotional aspect: if your software stops me and asks me to make a decision I don't understand, you make me feel stupid. Most people feel 'I'm dumb' not 'the software is stupid.' They associate that bad feeling with the product forever.
quotes.context: Expanding on the Don't Make Me Think mantra with biological and emotional reasoning

quotes.text: Google Calendar's time zone picker presents all time zones in alphabetical order. When I type E-A-S-T, first one is Eastern Australia, New South Wales. It's bananas how bad it is - used by hundreds of millions, presumably every Google employee. No one's going to switch from Outlook because the time zone picker is good, but there's real value in delighting customers. That emotional connection makes them recommend it or advocate for it when they switch companies.
quotes.context: Using Google Calendar as example of neglecting craft and its impact on emotional connection

quotes.text: When we shut down Glitch, there were people who loved it and would spend all their free time on it. That was their community and it just disappeared. People lost jobs, people who moved families to different cities. Pivots aren't something I take lightly. It's very different to be like 'there's three of us and we pivoted to a different app.' If you're six months in, you're still messing around. That doesn't even really count.
quotes.context: Reflecting on the painful human cost of pivoting from Glitch to Slack

takeaways: Tilt your umbrella - empathy for users' experience is your competitive advantage when most competitors are oblivious to their impact, creating emotional connections that drive organic advocacy

Utility curves guide investment decisions - the first effort produces no value, then hits a magic threshold of enormous value, then diminishing returns; know which part of the curve you're on before investing more

Comprehension beats friction reduction - most product challenges aren't about reducing clicks, they're about helping users understand what something does and why they should care without making them feel stupid

Pivot only after exhausting all realistic ideas - be coldly rational not emotional, because pivoting is humiliating after convincing investors/employees/users, but persevering past the point of viability is worse

Don't Make Me Think - every decision burns glucose and risks making users feel dumb, so ruthlessly eliminate comprehension barriers and obvious next actions to prevent users from associating bad feelings with your product

contrarian_candidates.why: Directly challenges the ubiquitous 'reduce friction' mantra - argues comprehension matters more than clicks, contradicting decades of UX conventional wisdom
Calling your own product 'a giant piece of shit' right after launch - extreme divine discontent that most founders would never publicly admit
Argues pivoting requires 'cold rationality' and admits it's 'fucking humiliating' - challenges the romanticized 'pivot early, pivot often' Silicon Valley narrative

episodes.episode_title: Tobi Ltke's leadership playbook: First principles, infinite games, and maximizing human potential

quotes.text: My energy source is dissatisfaction with status quo. I think today is the dystopia of the future. It behooves us to try to build the kinds of products that lead towards progress.
quotes.context: Describing what drives him as a founder and why he rejects copying existing solutions

quotes.text: A Tobi tornado is a whole lot of change management compressed into a very short timeframe. If I imagine something might not be the right thing to work on, I'm either incorrect or I'm correct - and it's super unfair for letting people work on something that isn't going to make it.
quotes.context: Explaining the 'Tobi tornado' phenomenon of rapidly killing projects when he realizes they won't work

quotes.text: I really, really, really think that there is not a single person on this planet who is even close to being at their maximum potential. Reminding people of their own potential constantly is actually a wonderful thing to do.
quotes.context: Explaining his philosophy of maximizing human potential through high standards and direct feedback

quotes.text: The most powerful unquantifiable things in the world of business are fun and delight. If all the metrics are pointing down but everyone says 'My God, I'm having so much more fun,' I think the very next thing that will happen with some time delay is all metrics will start going up.
quotes.context: Explaining why Shopify doesn't use OKRs and instead prioritizes unquantifiable things over metrics

quotes.text: Optimism always sounds dumb, or at least naive. Pessimism sounds extremely sophisticated. Metrics driven sounds sophisticated. Talking about fun sounds naive. But almost all of the alpha in the world is now in exactly the things that are unobvious but true.
quotes.context: Challenging conventional business aesthetics and why contrarian approaches often win

quotes.text: If you want to do something better than what exists, you have to do it differently. That's axiomatically not possible to do the same thing and get better results. It fails Archimedean logic.
quotes.context: Explaining why first principles thinking requires doing things differently from everyone else

quotes.text: 100 years, you can't talk about this software product but you can talk about the mission itself. Entrepreneurship is just precious. Shopify exists basically to make entrepreneurship more common.
quotes.context: Describing Shopify's 100-year vision and how long-term thinking shapes decision-making

quotes.text: On a long enough timeline, playing positive-sum games with your customers is the ultimate growth hack. The best companies resemble a room full of dials or levers for monetization. My job is adding as many of these levers as possible to the room, and then not pulling any of them.
quotes.context: Explaining why Shopify doesn't maximize short-term monetization despite having pricing power

quotes.text: The business world only talks about tactics - conversion optimization, A/B tests, growth hacks. I don't think that's important. The positional game is what matters: what territory are you taking? How much trust do you have? If you do that well, the tactics are yours. But if you extract through tactics all the value you created, you have nothing left in the tank.
quotes.context: Contrasting short-term tactical optimization with long-term strategic positioning

quotes.text: Goodhart's law: Any metric that becomes a goal ceases to be a good metric. It's the same as overfitting in machine learning. School optimizes for marks, and overfitting in school is literally kids cheating to get marks. We're extremely data-informed but we don't have KPIs because no metric by itself is a complete heuristic for a complex business.
quotes.context: Explaining why Shopify core product team operates without KPIs despite being extremely data-informed

quotes.text: Most of the time you end up in a bad part of a tree, in a local maxima of a path-dependent environment, by only making good choices. The presence of a downside of an idea does not disqualify the idea. You need to rerun the entire function over the state that is now updated with higher fidelity information.
quotes.context: Explaining why Shopify went fully remote during COVID by re-running first principles analysis when foundational assumptions changed

quotes.text: When someone disagrees with me, I immediately love it. I really crave it. I think courage is really rare. I found a lot more high IQ in industry than courage. I found a lot more genius than courage. What I'm looking for is unstated foundational assumptions - what is our divergence point?
quotes.context: Describing how to disagree with him and why he values courage over intelligence

takeaways: Dissatisfaction with status quo is a founder's energy source - today is the dystopia of the future, so we must build products that lead toward progress rather than accept conventional solutions

Maximize human potential through high standards and compressed feedback - no one is close to their maximum potential, and holding people accountable to that potential (not just current performance + 10%) unlocks extraordinary results

Prioritize unquantifiable things (fun, delight, quality) over pure metrics - Goodhart's law means any metric that becomes a goal ceases to be useful, so Shopify is data-informed but doesn't use KPIs or OKRs

Think in 100-year timeframes to make better decisions today - long-term thinking enables playing positive-sum games, resisting short-term value extraction, and building lasting strategic position over tactical wins

Re-run first principles analysis when foundational assumptions change - being in a local maxima from 'good choices' is dangerous; when core booleans flip (like COVID lockdowns), re-derive everything from scratch

contrarian_candidates.why: Directly challenges metrics-obsessed culture by arguing fun and delight matter more than quantifiable KPIs - sounds naive but produces better results
Argues that optimism and 'naive' approaches contain all the alpha while sophisticated pessimism leads astray - counterfactuals are winning
Rejects conventional monetization wisdom - builds levers for pricing power then deliberately doesn't pull them to play long-term positive-sum games

quotes.text: When you start small, it forces you to think about what is the problem that I'm going to solve. In all this advancements of the AI, one easy, slippery slope is to keep thinking about complexities of the solution and forget the problem that you're trying to solve.
quotes.context: Explaining why starting with minimal AI autonomy helps teams focus on the actual problem rather than getting lost in technical complexity

quotes.text: 74% or 75% of the enterprises that they had spoken to, their biggest problem was reliability. That's also why they weren't comfortable deploying products to their end users or building customer facing products because they just weren't sure or they just weren't comfortable doing that and exposing their users to a bunch of these risks.
quotes.context: Citing UC Berkeley/Databricks research on why enterprises struggle to deploy AI products

quotes.text: I used to work with the CEO of now Rackspace. He would have this block every day in the morning, which would say catching up with AI 4:00 to 6:00 AM. Leaders have to get back to being hands-on. You must be comfortable with the fact that your intuitions might not be right. And you probably are the dumbest person in the room and you want to learn from everyone.
quotes.context: Describing how successful AI transformation requires leaders to rebuild intuitions and be vulnerable about learning

quotes.text: If someone comes up to me and says, 'We have this one click agent, it's going to be deployed in your system and in two or three days, it'll start showing you significant gains,' I would almost be skeptical because it's just not possible. I probably will go as far to say that if someone's selling you one click-agents, it's pure marketing. To replace any critical workflow or to build something that can give you significant ROI, it easily takes four to six months of work, even if you have the best data layer and infrastructure layer.
quotes.context: Warning about unrealistic AI agent marketing and setting realistic expectations for enterprise AI deployment timelines

quotes.text: There's this false dichotomy of this either evals is going to solve everything or online monitoring or production monitoring is going to solve everything. I find no reason to trust one of the extremes. Evals are basically your trusted product thinking that is going into this set of data sets. Production monitoring is you're deploying your application and then you're having some sort of key metrics that actually communicate back to you on how customers are using your product.
quotes.context: Addressing the evals vs production monitoring debate by explaining they serve complementary purposes

quotes.text: Martin Fowler at some point had this term called semantic diffusion back in the 2000s, which kind of means that someone comes up with a term, everybody starts butchering it with their own definitions and then you kind of lose the actual definition of it. That is what is happening to evals or agents or any word in AI as of today, everybody kind of sees a different side to it.
quotes.context: Explaining why AI terminology like 'evals' and 'agents' has become confusing as different groups use the same terms for different concepts

quotes.text: Codex, we have this balanced approach of you need to have evals and you need to definitely listen to your customers. It's extremely hard to build an evaluation dataset for all kinds of interactions that your customers are going to use your product for. With that said, you also need to understand that if I'm going to make a change, it's at least not going to damage something that is really core to the product.
quotes.context: Explaining OpenAI Codex team's pragmatic approach combining evals for core functionality with heavy customer feedback monitoring

quotes.text: We built these end-to-end agents and we had to shut down the product because we were doing so many hot fixes and there was no way we could count all the emerging problems that were coming up. Recently, I think Air Canada had this thing where one of their agents predicted or hallucinated a policy for a refund, which was not part of their original playbook, and they had to go by it because legal stuff.
quotes.context: Sharing the origin story of the CCCD framework - real failures that led to developing the continuous calibration approach

quotes.text: Misunderstood is the concept of multi-agents. People have this notion of, 'I have this incredibly complex problem. Now I'm going to break it down into, hey, you are this agent. Take care of this. You're this agent. Take care of this.' It's never the case that there are incredibly successful multi-agent systems that are built. Letting the agents communicate in terms of peer-to-peer kind of protocol is incredibly hard to control.
quotes.context: Explaining why multi-agent systems where agents communicate peer-to-peer are misunderstood and harder than hierarchical supervisor patterns

quotes.text: Building is really cheap today. Design is more expensive, really thinking about your product, what you're going to build. Is it going to really solve a pain point? That is way more valuable today. And it will only become more true in the near future. So really obsessing about your problem and design is underrated and just rote building is overrated.
quotes.context: Arguing that in the AI era, implementation is becoming commoditized while thoughtful product design and problem definition are increasingly valuable

quotes.text: Implementation is going to be ridiculously cheap in the next few years. So really nail down your design, your judgment, your taste. And now we have AI that could help you ramp pretty quickly. After a few years, I think everybody's job becomes about your taste, your judgment and kind of what is uniquely you.
quotes.context: Discussing how AI shifts career value from execution mechanics to taste, judgment, and unique human perspective

quotes.text: Persistence is extremely valuable. Successful companies right now building in any new area, they are going through the pain of learning this, implementing this and understanding what works and what doesn't work. Pain is the new moat. That kind of knowledge that you built across the organization or across your own lived experiences, I feel that pain is what translates into the moat of the company.
quotes.context: Introducing the concept that going through the painful learning process of building AI products creates competitive advantage

quotes.text: Typically, you're bottlenecked where your ideas are not fitting in because they need to be made and they need to be made quickly. Now, you open up that bottleneck. So now actually making things is a lot easier. Actually, you become limited by how fast you can generate ideas.

I could imagine whatever five years from now, someone running a billion-dollar company with zero employees where it's like the support is handled by AI, the development is handled by AI, and you're just building and creating this thing.

The vision for Replit has always been is like, okay, making software is fun, is great, more people should do it, but so for more people to do it, it needs to be easier to do, it needs to be in one place, and it needs to be learnable.

I often go with minimalist prompts. That's also how I code as well. I have a vague idea for what I want to build and iterate from there. Other people, product managers like to write PRDs and more descriptive things, and you can do either of those things.
If you think about it's like we're building as you were building, so we're building out the agent so that it can continue getting better as our users are also building their applications.

When the cost of things go down, the total consumption of it goes up. And so I think that's going to be the case of software. As the costs go down, people will just make a lot more software to improve their lives and to improve their work and start more startups and all of that.

These silos between designers, product managers, and engineers. Everyone feels that pain of, we have low bandwidth communication, which is language and then text on Slack and Zoom calls. The common language that everyone shares is code. What if the language becomes actually working prototypes and working applications?

Being generative, being able to generate new ideas quickly, because you can think about it as a factory line. Typically you're bottlenecked by the middle part where your ideas are kind of like they're a lot of them and they're not fitting in, because they need to be made and they need to be made quickly. Now you open up that bottleneck. Actually, you become limited by how fast you can generate ideas.

The return on investment for learn to code is doubling every six months. Every six months, that's netting you more and more power because you're going to be able to create a lot more. It's going to be easier to create. You're going to be able to create a lot more complete things.

The way we work is going to change rapidly, and it's important to be resilient to that change. You want to be able to react to it really quickly. When the Anthropic drop the computer use set of capability, we slaughtered our roadmap. We immediately jumped on it and started building things. Being agile, not being stuck with roadmaps, being able to just say, oh, we're just going to switch priorities right away, is going to be super important.

You got to be fluid because when designers can code and engineers can design, it really becomes, you can't have a lot of structure around that. So you want to build a culture and you want to build an environment or milieu that is really, really flexible, which is uncomfortable for a lot of people.

It's so incredibly necessary in improving decision quality to take what's implicit and make it explicit. It's not that intuition is crap, your intuition is sometimes right. If you don't make it explicit, then you don't get to find out when it's wrong.
quotes.context: Explaining why structured decision-making processes outperform pure intuition, drawing from work with First Round Capital

quotes.text: People generally think the purpose of a meeting is for three things, discover, discuss, decide. The only thing that's ever supposed to happen in a meeting is the discussion part.
quotes.context: Introducing the concept of nominal groups - discovering opinions independently before meetings to avoid groupthink

quotes.text: The word alignment in terms of we're all aligned as a group is stupid and it shouldn't be used. People don't actually agree, they're not actually aligned on the decision. That's just the thing that makes you feel better.
quotes.context: Challenging the common goal of 'alignment' in meetings - arguing that forcing agreement creates coercion and ignores reality

quotes.text: The best way to get somebody's opinion is independently of other people's opinions, independently asynchronously. I want people to stop talking to each other so much. There's cross influence, the loudest person in the room tends to have an outsized influence on the decision.
quotes.context: Explaining why teams should collect opinions before meetings to avoid groupthink and anchoring bias

quotes.text: There is no such thing as a long feedback loop. You can make a decision about how long the feedback loop is. The way you choose to shorten the feedback loop is to say, what are the things that are correlated with the outcome that I eventually desire?
quotes.context: Pushing back on VCs who said they can't improve decision-making because feedback takes 10 years - explaining how to find leading indicators

quotes.text: A pre-mortem is great only if you set up kill criteria. Commit to actions that you're going to take if you see those signals. People won't quit until it actually isn't a decision. Until you've fallen in the crevasse already, then you'll make the decision to quit because then you know it was really bad.
quotes.context: Explaining why pre-mortems fail without pre-committed kill criteria - citing Richard Thaler's observation about delayed quitting

quotes.text: When Kahneman took hiring from completely unstructured to structured decision rubrics, the hit rate went from 50% to 65%. That's pretty huge. The problem is nobody does it. If you do it, the answer is quite a bit. But nobody does it.
quotes.context: Describing Daniel Kahneman's work on structured hiring and the implementation gap between knowing and doing

quotes.text: Nevertheless is a really good leadership skill. I hear you. Nevertheless, you're grounded for two weeks. I heard what you're saying and I understand. Nevertheless, this is what's going to happen. You have to have the balance between them feeling heard and following through on what you know or believe is right.
quotes.context: Teaching a leadership framework that acknowledges input while maintaining decision authority

quotes.text: Mental time travel is a really good decision tool. They would be really upset about something and I would say this is going to be so great for you when you're 40 at Thanksgiving. You're going to be able to tell these stories to your children. It allowed them to get some time and space from it to realize this is going to be funny at some point.
quotes.context: Describing how to use mental time travel to gain perspective on decisions that feel huge in the moment

quotes.text: By the time you quit, it's probably long after you ought to have quit. When we walk away, we feel like we'll have wasted everything that we've already put into what we're doing. But of course, waste is a prospective problem, not a retrospective one. Everything that you're putting into this going forward is the actual waste.
quotes.context: Explaining sunk cost fallacy and why people wait too long to quit projects, jobs, or relationships

quotes.text: Stewart Butterfield shut down Glitch when they had $6 million in the bank, 5,000 diehard users, and growing 6-7% week over week. He woke up with dead certainty that Glitch was over. Two days later, he's like, 'Maybe that internal communication tool should be the next product.' That thing now gets a name: Slack.
quotes.context: Iconic example of strategic quitting - Stewart couldn't see Slack until he quit Glitch despite apparent success

quotes.text: When we think about something as simple as forecasting how long it's going to take to launch a product feature, if you're senior and you say 'I think this is going to take three months' and I was thinking four weeks, you're never going to hear four weeks from me, ever. But if we get those opinions independently, you will actually hear that I think it's going to take four weeks.
quotes.context: Explaining how independent forecasting reveals true disagreement that gets hidden in meetings due to hierarchy and conformity

quotes.text: 40 to 60% of B2B purchase processes end in no decision. The majority of those couldn't figure out how to make a choice confidently. So what they did was they just went to their boss and said, 'You know what? Now's not a good time. Let's not do it now. Let's do it next year.'
quotes.context: Explaining why B2B buyers delay decisions - not because status quo is better, but because they're overwhelmed and afraid of making the wrong choice

quotes.text: What B2B software buyers want in a sales interaction is perspectives on the market and help weighing their options. And we don't do that. We're just like, 'Here's our stuff. You figure it out, it's up to you.'
quotes.context: Contrasting what buyers actually need versus what sales teams typically provide

quotes.text: The way we combat buyer indecision is not just talking about ourselves, it's actually about trying to be helpful to that person in this very stressful situation that is trying to figure out how do I make a really good decision.
quotes.context: Describing the shift from product-centric to buyer-centric sales approach

quotes.text: If a customer is indecisive, throwing FOMO into the mix makes it worse. They're less likely to close the deal if you throw that in. They're already stressed out and you're just putting more stress on them by pressuring them.
quotes.context: Citing research from The JOLT Effect that studied 2.5 million sales calls

quotes.text: There is this secondary job that the champion of the deal has, and that's how do I make a decision without getting fired? And so we got to help them accomplish that job, otherwise we don't get what we want, which is the money.
quotes.context: Discussing Jobs To Be Done framework applied to B2B software buying

quotes.text: Once we realize that the champion is the key, then we can get really tight on our positioning in our sales pitch. What we're really trying to do is just cook the champion, and then once the deal's going we got to arm the champion for how to handle all these objections of all these other groups.
quotes.context: Explaining B2B buying complexity with 5-7 stakeholders involved

quotes.text: Differentiated value is the answer to the question why pick us over the other alternatives? It's value that the other guys can't deliver because they don't have the capabilities that underpin it.
quotes.context: Defining the core concept that drives effective positioning and sales pitches

quotes.text: The posture we should have is calm confidence. We really understand why people should pick us. We should be able to come in and say, 'Look, if you don't care about those results, you shouldn't pick us. You should pick someone else.'
quotes.context: Describing the ideal sales posture when discussing competitors

quotes.text: Obviously creating a category is not the only way to create a legendary business because the vast majority of legendary businesses did not create the categories that they're in. Google did not create search, Facebook did not create social network.
quotes.context: Pushing back on the 'category creation or bust' narrative

quotes.text: Most category creators actually get overtaken by fast followers. What happened to MySpace? What happened to Ask Jeeves? Most category creators wins their market. Like what happened to MySpace? It didn't work out so good for them.
quotes.context: Challenging the myth that category creators always dominate their markets

quotes.text: In the work I do with clients, generally what we're working on is a shift in the positioning. For the most part what was happening in the sales pitch is there was no positioning going on at all. The sales pitch was essentially a product exposition, just feature, feature, feature, feature, feature.
quotes.context: Diagnosing the core problem with most B2B sales pitches

quotes.text: I worked at a company where I was the VP marketing, and we, within two quarters, had doubled the revenue just by tightening up the pitch. Just tighten it up. Most of the time, the pitches are so bad that if we could improve it even a little bit, it actually has this big impact.
quotes.context: Sharing the concrete business impact of improving sales positioning and pitch structure

quotes.text: Success is a series of bad decisions. None of the decisions by themselves is that bad, but when you add them up, it's bad. And if you can break psychologically, you can take the sunk cost, then that gets you out of a lot of bad paths. A small good decision may be difficult, but you have to believe it's going to lead to the next one. A lot of success is about that. It's a small thing, a small thing that's hard to do that doesn't seem to have a high impact, but it leads to the next small hard to do thing.
quotes.context: Sharing the pilot's lesson about JFK Jr.'s plane crash - how small bad decisions compound

quotes.text: All the things that you perceive that are happening to you that are bad, be it the systems against you or somebody undercuts you or racism or sexism or this or that or the other is very small compared to what you do to yourself. If you believe what people say about you, if you believe what they did to you, then that destroys you. But if you go, 'That's not me,' you can overcome almost anything.
quotes.context: Shaka Senghor's lesson from 19 years in prison - self-beliefs matter more than external obstacles

quotes.text: The biggest mistake that you make, the worst thing that you do as a leader is hesitation. And the thing that causes you to hesitate is both decisions are horrible. What happens to you as CEO, it's like, 'Okay, if we rearchitect this product, I kind of know it's not going to get us to where we need to go. But if we rearchitect it, we're going to probably miss all the features, miss the quarter, have trouble raising money.' So both are really bad, and so I'm just going to try to avoid this subject because I don't even want to deal with either of those. And that's the worst thing.
quotes.context: Explaining why hesitation is the most destructive thing leaders do when faced with two horrible options

quotes.text: We went public with $2 million in trailing 12 months revenue at 18 months old. That's obviously a bad idea. But the truth of it was the alternative because of where the private markets were was going bankrupt. And that's a worse idea. The Wall Street Journal wrote a whole long story about how stupid I was. And then Businessweek wrote a story called the IPO From Hell. But it wasn't as bad as bankruptcy.
quotes.context: Loudcloud IPO story - choosing public humiliation over bankruptcy in March 2001

quotes.text: The psychological muscle you have to build to be a great leader is to be able to look in the abyss and go, 'Okay, that way's slightly better. We're going to go that way.' If everybody agrees with the decision, then you didn't add any value because they would've done that without you. So the only value you ever add is when you make a decision that most people don't like.
quotes.context: Defining the core psychological muscle of leadership - making unpopular decisions

quotes.text: The only reason to start a company is because you have an irrational desire to do so, because it's not worth the money. When we sold LoudCloud for $1.6 billion, I remember thinking, 'Wow, that wasn't worth the money whatsoever.' You really have to have an irrational desire to do something larger than yourself to improve the world in some way that somehow that is your purpose. If you don't feel that, then you'll never get through it.
quotes.context: John Reed's advice on why to start a company - must have irrational purpose-driven desire

quotes.text: They were like, 'We need to raise $200,000.' And I said, 'Look, I'm not going to write you a check for $200,000. I'll write you a check for $10 million because this company, you need to build a company. You need to really go for it if you're going to do this, otherwise you guys should stay in school.' You need to really go for it. Otherwise you should just stay in school.
quotes.context: Databricks funding story - forcing founders to think bigger when they had Spark competing with Hadoop

quotes.text: What I was trying to get out in Good Product Manager, Bad Product Manager, was the job is fundamentally a leadership job. And it's a tricky leadership job because nobody is actually reporting to you. Your actual job is to get a product into market that customers love that's better than anything that anybody else in the world puts in market. That's your job. And so you need to be the leader. You've got to get the thing done.
quotes.context: Explaining the core insight from his famous Good Product Manager, Bad Product Manager essay

quotes.text: From the perspective of the PM, it doesn't matter if you write a good spec or you have a good interview or you do this or do that. What matters is that the product works. You're not necessarily the person who comes up with every idea. You're just the keeper of the vision. That's true for CEOs too. There's somebody who's got to consolidate, get all the good ideas, prioritize them, decide which good ideas we're going to do, and then get everybody on the same page.
quotes.context: Clarifying what PM and CEO roles really are - keepers of vision, not just idea generators

quotes.text: You don't judge a person by the worst thing that ever happened to them. We've all had bad things happen to us. We've all made bad decisions.
