You want to judge people on what they do well, not what they screwed up, because that's where you see the talent. If you look at what Adam did well with WeWork, it's truly spectacular. Name a more important commercial real estate brand than WeWork. You can't.
quotes.context: Defending investing in Adam Neumann after WeWork - focus on strengths not failures

quotes.text: Venture capital is really about investing in people. We're investing in strength, not lack of weakness. I want to know, are they world-class? Do they have a world-class strength? And can that beat anybody? Look, everybody's flawed. So let's help them deal with the flaws and surround them with people who can handle that. You don't throw them away and go, 'We don't want to be called names.'
quotes.context: Philosophy of investing in people - bet on world-class strengths, help with weaknesses

quotes.text: The products are working so much better than any technology product that we've ever built has worked. It's just mind-blowing how good this stuff is. These businesses are all working, and they're being priced appropriately for how they're growing. The thing that made the dot-com bubble was the unit economics didn't work, the businesses didn't work. That's not happening now. If I had to bet, I would bet not a bubble.
quotes.context: Arguing AI is not a bubble unlike dot-com - unit economics actually work, unprecedented product-market fit

quotes.text: Communication is the job. If you want to have an impact on the world around you, it is exclusively done through the creation of artifacts or verbalizations that affect other humans. That is all there is. People always think, 'Oh, I had that idea.' It means nothing. It means absolutely nothing. Or 'Oh, I wrote this post.' Well, you didn't break through with it. That's on you.
quotes.context: Explaining his most famous principle that having ideas means nothing without effective communication

quotes.text: The advice I find I have to give more frequently than any other is for people to more directly leverage their leaders. We want to do it ourselves to prove we can. But your job is not to do it yourself. Your job is to get it done. The tools you need live with your manager, your partner, your mentor. Nobody wants you to succeed more than your manager does, because when you're amazing, their life gets easier.
quotes.context: Sharing his most frequently given career advice about asking managers for help

quotes.text: I don't want to take away from the romanticism of it. It's just that most often, we hear those romantic stories from the successes. It's a healthy thing for people to want to throw themselves into something and take that risk, but it is not glamorous at the time. I worked 120 hours per week, I didn't sleep for more than four hours at a time, I'd wake up every four hours and check if anyone was attacking the site.
quotes.context: Describing the unglamorous reality of early Facebook days as the 10th engineer

quotes.text: We joke inside of Meta, to this day, we call it the eye of Sauron. When Mark has determined that the thing you're working on is the most important thing, there is no detail too small for him to notice. He will be in a review and say, 'Strategically, I think we're off course. And also, this one pixel is definitely wrong. You have to fix that.' That's a big range.
quotes.context: Explaining the legendary 'eye of Sauron' metaphor for founder attention to detail

quotes.text: Multimodality. Repetition never spoiled the prayer. I will give an all-hands and then write a post with the content of the all-hands, because different people are going to respond differently to these modalities. Making sure that you address people's fears and concerns right up top. People will not listen to you if they think you don't know what's going on.
quotes.context: Sharing practical techniques for effective communication at scale

quotes.text: Identity threat is just the biggest threat. Your worst behavior is always going to come out when you think you're under identity threat. When you feel like some core part of how you see yourself is in question, you will react with every ounce of your fiber to defend that conception of yourself because it's so expensive to reconceptualize who you are.
quotes.context: Explaining why he got into an embarrassing technical argument with his best friend Dave Federman

quotes.text: Ami Vora could have the most profound disagreement with somebody and they would say the thing she thought was not just wrong, but crazy wrong. She would respond, 'Fascinating. You have to tell me more about why you think that.' She meant it from the core of her being. She saw this schism between her and that person and reacted with the most genuine and profound curiosity.
quotes.context: Describing the transformative leadership lesson he learned from watching Ami Vora handle disagreement

quotes.text: News Feed was an easier case than people suspect. Everyone was outraged at the same time as they immediately doubled their usage of the product. We had cognitive dissonance between stated preferences and revealed preferences in the economic sense. So we were like, Okay, there's something real here.
quotes.context: Explaining how they had conviction to stick with News Feed despite user backlash by watching actual behavior

quotes.text: Mark is somebody who is maybe the strongest willpower of a person I've ever met. You'll give him feedback, he'll listen. He'll most often tell you that you're wrong, why you're wrong. What will happen is over the course of the next week or two, you'll just see shifts. The information gets to him, and at night he re-compiles the whole world with all that information and comes back.
quotes.context: Describing Mark Zuckerberg's unique way of processing feedback and iterating on his mental model

quotes.text: Gell-Mann Amnesia: You'll read a newspaper article about a thing you're an expert in, and you'll be baffled because it's not just wrong, it's inverted causality. It's a 'wet sidewalks make rain' story. And then you turn the page and it's another article about a topic you know nothing about, and you'll read it as if it's gospel truth. You know more than the critics do.
quotes.context: Explaining why Meta's team needed to trust their own expertise during the stock downturn rather than external narratives

quotes.text: Extreme ownership: Whenever thing goes wrong, I ask myself, what could I have done differently in terms of how I communicated things for this to have gone better? I give somebody a piece of work and they come back six months later and they have done the wrong thing, I'll take the L. That's my responsibility. I did not communicate clearly what I wanted.
quotes.context: Explaining how he applies extreme ownership from US Marines/SEALs to all communication failures

quotes.text: The motto my family has is just trust yourself. I really think so much of the success I've had was just having faith that I was making good decisions. You have to believe you, your eyes, ears and intellect have combined to give you a point of view that has intrinsic value and deserves your respect. Trusting yourself also includes taking risks because you trust that you can deal with what happens when the risks don't pay out.
quotes.context: Sharing his family's life motto and how conviction in yourself enables both risk-taking and resilience

quotes.speaker: Brian Chesky
quotes.text: Leaders are in the details. And there's this negative term called micromanagement. I think there's a difference between micromanagement, which is like telling people exactly what to do, and being in the details. Being in the details is what every responsible company's board does to the CEO. That doesn't mean the board is telling them what to do. But if you don't know the details, how do you know people are doing a good job?

quotes.speaker: Brian Chesky
quotes.text: You can't build a product unless you know how to talk about the product. You can't be an expert in making the product unless you're also an expert in the market of it. If you build a great product and no one knows about it, did you even build a product?

quotes.speaker: Brian Chesky
quotes.text: We wanted a company where a thousand people could work, but it'll look like 10 people did it.

quotes.speaker: Brian Chesky
quotes.text: I think the CEO should be basically the chief product officer of a product or tech company. If the CEO is not the chief product officer then I don't know if they're a product or tech led company.

quotes.speaker: Brian Chesky
quotes.text: The less involved I was in the project, the more spin there was, the less clear the goals, the less advocacy the team had, the less resources, the fewer resources they had. And then therefore the slower they moved. And the slower they moved, the more they assumed it was because I was too involved.

quotes.speaker: Brian Chesky
quotes.text: There's a great saying that the best way to slow a project down is add more people to it. We have fewer than 7,000 employees today. As a relative comparison, I think Uber has 30,000. And it's not to say they're big, it's just say that's how small we are and we've really benefited from having not a lot of employees.

quotes.speaker: Brian Chesky
quotes.text: A design leader's job should be managing the design first, the people second. That's what Jony did. I could never imagine Jony out at Apple just being a manager of people. He was looking and designing the work with the team. How do you manage the people without managing their work? How do you give them development if you're not in the details with them on the work?

quotes.speaker: Brian Chesky
quotes.text: Way too many founders apologize for how they want to run the company. They find some midpoint between how they want to run a company and how the people they lead want to run the company. That's a good way to make everyone miserable. Because what everyone really wants is clarity. And what everyone really wants is to be able to row in the same direction really quickly.

quotes.speaker: Brian Chesky
quotes.text: Five teams should do one thing rather than one team do five things. People should work together. I think that people should consider doing launches. You can by the way, ship every hour of every day, but then package it and tell a story if you want hold the product back.

quotes.speaker: Brian Chesky
quotes.text: Everyone should row in the same direction. If there's only one thing I said in this interview today, actually I'm not sure what it would be, but I think a good candidate is try to get everyone to row together in the same direction. Otherwise, why the hell are you all in the same company?

A lot of managers and leaders would just try to deal with issues on their own and not raise them or escalate them with me. And some of these were really tough situations, so then later on, I'd ask why something went wrong. And I get feedback like, you don't understand the situation. Yeah, of course I don't understand this situation because you haven't told me about it. These people on my team thought that being a leader was handling it the best they could given the circumstances when in many cases the right way is to escalate the issue so that perhaps I could help them change the circumstances. I find that in general people just way under communicate upward inside of companies. And then they'll complain that executives are out of touch when they aren't telling executives what the executives need to know.
quotes.context: Explaining why communication upward is critical for leadership effectiveness

quotes.text: If you're not an executive, whatever you're working on, you're basically writing and telling a story. And when you talk to an exec about that story, you have to start with chapter one, which is what part of the company strategy are you working on? What metrics are you trying to improve? What assumptions are you making? Many times when non-executives are presenting to execs, they'll start on like chapter six, so even if that part of the story is right, you haven't earned the right to tell that part of the story yet because you skipped the first five chapters.
quotes.context: Teaching PMs how to communicate effectively with executives

quotes.text: Executive communication is actually executives communication. You're communicating with individual executives that all have different styles and different concerns about the business or about the particular problem you're working on. And you want to anticipate that. The other thing that I push a lot of my team to do is have pre-meetings with some of those key individuals, so that they're going to be less surprised in the meeting about what you're talking about, that you've gotten any major concerns brought to your attention before the big meeting. And that helps de-risk how poorly a meeting like that can go.
quotes.context: Coaching PMs on how to prepare for important executive presentations

quotes.text: For any of these types of communications, how well do you really know the material, and how well do you really know what your audience is going to care about with that material so that you are prepared for every question you might get. If you haven't thought through all the questions that might be asked from the document that you're sharing or the presentation you're about to present, you're not prepared enough. You need to know the entire universe of how that meeting can go. And that may take you dozens of hours, it might take you three hours, but the most important thing is that you've asked what possible questions can be asked and am I prepared to answer all of those?
quotes.context: Explaining the importance of thorough preparation for key meetings

quotes.text: The way that a lot of key decisions are made inside companies are through these types of forums and meetings. And it's an extremely high leverage piece of time for a product manager or a product designer in terms of how much impact they can have. If you are under preparing for those sorts of things, the chances of you being able to have the type of impact you want, to have the type of career growth you want just go down dramatically.
quotes.context: Emphasizing why meeting preparation is high-leverage work for PMs

quotes.text: We strive for this concept of what we call perceived simplicity, which is there are advanced features in the product and they are easily discoverable when you look for them, but they're effectively hidden if you're not looking for them. And of course the majority of users aren't going to ever look for them, so the advanced more complex areas of the product don't make the product harder to use for the majority who will never need that level of complexity. WhatsApp does the best job of this. At its core, it's a chat app and it's really good at being a chat app. It would take less than a second to figure out how to use the more advanced stuff, but it's effectively kind of hidden if you're not looking for it.
quotes.context: Explaining Eventbrite's approach to adding complexity while maintaining simplicity

quotes.text: Some of the most impactful projects that product teams can work on at scale are the hardest to measure. And because of that, they just get chronically underfunded. For things like user experience, or performance, or developer velocity, or just a product area that's deemed un-sexy, you have to get a team to buy-in to this. You can't really do a lot of this work alone. If you can get a small team, like two, three people aligned on the importance of something that's deemed un-sexy, it's a lot easier to start to build this game plan around metrics or running small tests or structuring OKRs to not only prioritize this work, but to show some really massive impact. Which could then get the rest of the company much more excited to make investments themselves.
quotes.context: Discussing how to justify non-sexy product investments like stability and performance

quotes.text: When you're an early stage company, everything you're doing is trying to drive upside, trying to drive growth. But when you've actually built a real business, a lot of times people are still in that same mode. But when you're at scale, you can actually lose what you've built. Trying to help whether it's executives or just your manager, understand that this thing we've got, whether it's a high conversion rate or good engagement on this feature, it could go away if we don't do these other things. And here's what it would look like if that goes away, that can be incredibly powerful. Protecting what we've got actually is increasingly important once you build scale, because now you've built something really valuable already.
quotes.context: Explaining the shift from pure growth to protecting value at scale

quotes.text: User expectations just continue to go up every day in terms of their expectations on user experience, on the value that they expect your product to provide, but also the competitive landscape in the market continues to get better. If you're not continually pushing to make your product better, your user experience better, your latency better, then you're eventually not necessarily tomorrow, but maybe in a year, maybe in five years, you might find yourself fall out of product market fit entirely. And that's a really dangerous place to be, because then it's going to take a long time to figure that out and make adjustments.
quotes.context: Warning that product-market fit erodes over time without continuous improvement

quotes.text: Product leaders can struggle with assuming that questions from executives are them trying to learn versus them assuming you don't know something and testing you about it. I find that a lot of people get intimidated by executive questions when the executive is just trying to understand things. And then that changes the interaction you can have. Refusing to specialize served me well. I thought if I could learn all the skills that would allow me to combine them to work on the most important things versus only work on the thing I knew how to work on. That was a much faster path to the true executive role because I could speak better with CEOs about more topics than most of my peers.
quotes.context: Sharing advice on how to get to CPO level

quotes.text: Early on in your career as a PM, you're going to get the most value by showing that you can ship real things to customers and that the customers like them. But if you want to start managing groups of PMs, if you want to start running a business unit, or a pillar, or a theme. I as a chief product officer, I'm going to expect you to be able to write that strategy doc without me. A lot of people couldn't do that step. And that means when you try to become a product leader at the company and the CEO expects that from you and you can't do it, you're going to set yourself up to really cap hard on how fast your career can grow. That's definitely where I've seen the biggest bottleneck in terms of skill sets. That one to get to the top is the great filter.
quotes.context: Explaining that strategic thinking is the key skill for PMs to advance to leadership

quotes.text: The goal of your kindle strategies, these like non-scalable hacks, they only exist to unlock the fire strategies, to unlock the things that could take you to millions of users. It's once you unlock a fire strategy, that's when I think you think about hiring someone full time on growth to fully harness that new growth loop you've built. I still think data network effects are underrated. Leveraging product usage data to make the product value stronger and stronger over time. That could be personalized results in the case of Pinterest or better targeting data for advertising. Especially with Facebook and Apple's platform changes your product being able to generate its own data, versus just relying on the big platforms to do all the work for you. That's a real edge.
quotes.context: Discussing growth strategy phases and the power of data network effects

quotes.text: One of my mantras is just don't die. Just keep your startup going. Just keep going. And I say that over and over again and honestly, that is often what people tell me is the most impactful thing I said. It's not that I said some Ninja 5D chess move that they never would've thought of before. It's just the constant affirmation that continuing to keep going and doing high quality reps is the game.
quotes.context: Explaining why simple pragmatic advice like 'don't die' is more impactful than complex strategic advice

quotes.text: The underlying theme is that rationally the founder should have given up at some point. They probably should have shut down three or four times before they got into YC. It objectively wasn't working. They were basically ruining their lives, they were disappointing their parents, everything was wrong and it was a purely irrational act for the founders of Airbnb to keep working on their goofy startup.
quotes.context: Using Airbnb as example of irrational persistence leading to success

quotes.text: Are you still having fun? Do you still enjoy doing what you're doing? Do you enjoy spending time with your co-founders? Is this actually a fun thing you're doing? If the answer there is yes, I would tend to lean on the keep going. Something that a lot of the folks that turn it around have in common is they actually do love their customers and they love their product.
quotes.context: Practical advice on when to keep going vs when to shut down a struggling startup

quotes.text: A good pivot is like going home. It's warmer, it's closer to something that you're an expert at. And it never occurred to you that this thing you know all about would be a good idea or maybe you consciously are like, 'I don't want to work on this because burnt out on it.' Sometimes someone has to get over this barrier they have on why they don't want to work on a certain idea.
quotes.context: Explaining what makes a successful pivot - moving towards expertise rather than away from it

quotes.text: There's no universe where they would've made up the idea for Segment because they didn't know anything about how analytics worked, but because they were grinding for multiple years and became experts on these things as a side effect of their earlier ideas, they ended up with really good unique insights.
quotes.context: Segment's multi-year pivot story - expertise built through struggling on earlier ideas

quotes.text: The weird aspect of what we call a tarpit idea is an idea that a lot of people come up with and then it seems like an unsolved problem and you get lots of positive feedback for. You have a really good set of arguments that it's a really good startup idea. Man, people have been starting that startup since the '90s and so you can validate it. Part of being a true tarpit is that you can get good initial validation.
quotes.context: Defining 'tarpit ideas' - ideas that seem great and validate well but consistently fail

quotes.text: My best advice here is for founders to put themselves in the shoes of investors and just imagine what their life is like and how if you are in their shoes you would make decisions. A lot of investors just don't make that many investments and as per what we talked about earlier, life is short. Anything that doesn't seem like this is the one, this is the one I want to do is a no.
quotes.context: Explaining why investors say no - not necessarily flaws in your startup, but better alternatives

quotes.text: The TAM of Uber would be nothing. The TAM of Airbnb would've been nothing. I funded Razorpay, which is the largest payment processor in India, and the TAM of that was tiny because no one was using credit cards in 2015 in India. You had to believe that the size of the credit card industry in India would 100X. Well, guess what happened? Trying to be super pedantic about market size when it's a pre-seed company or someone applying to YC, it's just not something I'd put a lot of thought.
quotes.context: Arguing TAM analysis is overrated at early stages - markets can be created

quotes.text: You can't delegate caring about your users and you can't delegate caring that the product is great. That is so critical. You end up with super nice people with super shiny resumes from big tech companies and then you wake up one day and you're like, 'Oh wow, everything went wrong.' It's not really anyone's fault, it's just that you took your eye off the ball.
quotes.context: Warning about over-delegating and hiring fancy executives too early

quotes.text: I think is that the founders lose hope. And when you and your heart is like, 'Yeah, we're failing.' I can see it when I'm meeting with a founder, when they resign themselves that they're failing versus when like, 'We got one more move in us. We got one more try.' It's much more common that they still have some money left and they're just like, 'Yeah, I'm done. I'm out of ideas. I don't want to do this anymore.'
quotes.context: Explaining the real reason startups fail - losing hope rather than running out of money

quotes.text: If we define it as the company had a near death experience where it was going poorly and the founders seriously wondered if it was all going to be over, a hundred percent of the time people go through that. At least you feel that way at some point in your startup journey, man, everyone goes through that. Maybe 50% truly got down to very, very hard situations. There's a lot of founders that come this close to it all being over and through sheer will just keep it going.
quotes.context: Revealing that 100% of successful founders experience near-death moments

quotes.text: You can do a self-assessment. In the past month, how many in-person physical meetings have I had with potential customers? Look at your calendar and there should be 20 or 30% of your time that the calendar says something like customer meeting, customer call. Nothing substitutes for an actual conversation versus just staring at analytics dashboards.
quotes.context: Giving specific heuristic for how much time founders should spend talking to customers

quotes.text: Design is art applied to problem solving. I think that design is often... There is some component of creativity to it and unique expression that you're trying to provide and create and put out into the world. But you are also trying to do it and match it to a user need, a problem that needs to be solved. And I think that it's not pure art, but if you lose the art and you're just solving the problem, it's totally utilitarian and it lacks soul.

Intuition is like a hypothesis generator and you're constantly generating these hypotheses and others are generating hypotheses as well. And you then take these hypotheses and you put them forward and you debate them and you try to find data to support them or negate them. And then you winnow it down into what is our working hypothesis? And from that you move forward.

I think the more concrete an artifact is or the more you can debate something, the better. I ask for examples a lot, I try to ask follow up questions about things and make sure I fully understand it. And I think where I get stuck sometimes is if I ask follow up questions and we don't have answers yet, and then my response might be, 'Let's go find the answer to these questions and then let's go back to this conversation.'

Good product people are able to create great frameworks that bring everyone along with them. And so everyone's able to have a shared head space around what it is they're trying to get to. The best PMs create those frameworks that bring everyone else along and those frameworks also have a point of view and a strategy associated with them. So you're able to take the strategy, take the point of view, wrap it all up in a framework, and then make it so that everyone knows what the destination is and how to get there.

One plus one does not equal three, it sometimes equals one and a half. And the more that you add and the more that you continue to put in something, the more complex it gets and the worse it gets. And I think this is definitely true for tools. We can make it more powerful, but to do that in a way that's not making it more complex at the same time is extremely hard.

Keep the simple things simple. Make the complex things possible. I think that's a really important principle to hold as you're designing tools. And I'd say that it's really easy to make the simple things complex, unfortunately.

Get it out as fast as you possibly can. Everything they tell you about making sure that you get a product out really quickly is totally true. The faster you get it out, the more feedback you get. That is a positive thing. And now I index on that when we try to build.

For a new launch, you got quality, features, deadline, choose two. And I think that the beautiful thing about software is you can keep iterating on it. So it's not like a physical product where you have to always have quality in there, otherwise it's never going to have quality. You can ship it with features and deadline and then improve it iteratively over time.

I constructed this list of, 'Here are the most central designers in the graph', but also then I looked at their work. And the ones that I was really inspired by as a total fanboy, and someone who wanted to learn as much as I could about design, was inspired by these folks, the ones I was inspired by I reached out to and said, 'Hey, can I buy you a coffee?' And I think it started honestly more as me fanboy and me getting feedback.

When people give you advice, they're not giving you advice, they're giving themselves advice in your shoes. I think that's an interesting one. So if I gave you advice here, I'm giving myself advice in your shoes.

Mentors can come from anywhere. It can come from the community. Mentorship can come from the people you hire. It can come from folks that you actively seek out as investors or explicit mentorship and mentors. There have been plenty of people where they ask me a question at some point and I give them an answer and they think it's insightful for whatever reason. And then years later where we're talking again and I ask them a question and they're like, 'Well, years ago you told me...' And they repeat back what I told them like, 'That's a really good point.'

You have to fail to learn. You can't just constantly succeed. Success is an output of a lot of failures, but the question is, how much time do you have to fail? And a lot of times we don't realize how many failure cycles we're going to have to go through before we get a success, and that company, or even market, has no time for that.

Growth cannot function without data. If you have 10 users or 10 customers, that's not data, that's a G-sheet with your customers and you don't need a growth team for that. Until you have data that you can actually do an analysis and you can create hypotheses on and you can start applying experimentation, don't even think about growth team.

Growth can amplify great product market fit and growth can help you grow faster once you are already growing. But if you are slowing down and you have issues with either your go-to-market strategy or your core product strategy with your core product market fit, growth is going to be absolutely helpless to do anything.

Never ever once have I seen a rebrand or redesign, especially of UK marketing site produce good performance results. New CMO comes in designing their website or designing the brand as if it was reflection of their personal taste, and oftentimes it's promised with our acquisition is going to go up and it never materializes into anything meaningful.

Benchmarks are usually done on all of the competition, on all of the softwares out there. And the way people define numbers is so different from company to company. Even if you look as something as simple as signups. So taking also any benchmark that is derived from competition and saying, 'This is where we should be,' is also so dangerous because it might not even be applicable depending on how you define the metric.
There are patterns and there are frameworks, but there's no shortcuts.

Your problem is not unique. I am 99% sure of that. Your problem has been felt by somebody somewhere in probably many, many places and you trying to re-engineer solution is time lost to market and has a huge opportunity cost. Do not start from scratch. It's the worst thing that you can do because you can waste so many cycles on trying to do something that probably has already been solved.

Focusing on these earned channels that you own becomes the outmost priority. And if you don't have them on your growth roadmap, you are going to be in some really big trouble over the next year to two years because your cost of acquisition is only going to go up. Your competition and those channel is only going to go up.

If every single one of your initiatives that you're doing on growth is an experiment, that's a problem. It's almost like a disease, like a paralyzing disease, that slows down progress, that slows down velocity, that slows down learnings, that creates very terrible consequences to the output that growth teams produce.

Data is good, but data is only good if you have enough of it. So if you have low volume real estate, that is going to take you eight months to reach some sort of answer. Do you really want to test it for eight months? My rule of thumb, if we cannot collect the sample size in the month, we shouldn't test it, period.

People stop in this age of data, almost rely enough on their element intuition. Experimentation cannot be the way that people make decisions in the company. There's still so much about knowing your user, understanding the market for your brain to connect all of those dots and to know what needs to be an experience that your customers are going to want.

Growth teams are often too obsessed about removing friction. If you ever have a line item on your roadmap that says simplified onboarding, please cross it out. It's not going to work because simplifying onboarding is an action. What is the problem that you're solving? You always have a problem of people are confused in it, but people don't know where to go or they get lost in it or they're not educated enough. That is the problem.

I basically became a part-time PM for them nights and weekends. Within three months this thing grew big enough and that became Google AdSense. It's very important to do a core job really well at any company, but it's equally important to have curiosity and be open to serendipity. Great careers are built by knowing a lot of people doing great work so they know and want you on their teams, and just waiting for serendipity and then seizing it and jumping.
quotes.context: Describing how he accidentally created Google AdSense by wandering around the office at 6pm and asking engineers what they were working on

quotes.text: I could never ever imagine that I could be passionate about payments ever in a million years, but the environment of the company Square was so infectious and great and the culture was so good that we even made working on payments... I always think of, not what you're working on but what problem you're solving. I get much more energy from personally solving problems that affected a small business or basically people or small business that I can relate to.
quotes.context: Explaining how he found passion in unexpected places and why customer segment matters more than the problem domain

quotes.text: It's very important for founders to really live and breathe the mission themselves in an authentic way. If people are smart, and I think you've got to really honestly think if this person is constantly talking about revenue and trying to convince you that you're going to get wealthy or they're going to get... That's not the kind of founder that's going build a really large company. They care about winning. They will win and money will come, but it's a side product.
quotes.context: Describing what to look for in founders when deciding where to work - authentic mission over money

quotes.text: I would much rather be the number two or number three person at the leader in a space, than the top person. Google versus Yahoo. I saw even if you're the VP of product at Yahoo or the head of product at Yahoo versus a ICPM at Google, you probably want to be the ICPM at Google. I bet you all day long. Yahoo is a great company, but Google is just a different caliber and different class.
quotes.context: Explaining why working at winning companies matters more than titles, using Google vs Yahoo as example

quotes.text: One of the most interesting things I've realized is there are multiple paths to greatness. Google would be technical. Facebook was very growth focused. Square was very design focused. DoorDash by nature is more operational. I think there are multiple paths to greatness, but I think the founder and market fit in terms of even the type of company that's needed is very strong. Founders have to be authentic to themselves.
quotes.context: Comparing the different DNA of successful companies he's worked at and why founder authenticity matters

quotes.text: The product itself ideally needs to have some remarkability. It needs to be better than anything else that solves that pain point along a few dimensions that really matter. A good metric is that 40 to 50% of your new customers should ideally come from organic channels and 50% from paid. If 90% come from paid, that means at some point that the music is going to stop.
quotes.context: Explaining why products need organic growth and word-of-mouth, not just paid acquisition

quotes.text: The right time for PMs to join the company is about eight to 10 engineers or so. The role of the PM is actually to be the liaison between the founder, founders and the engineering team. And so it needs to be someone that the founders trust and the engineering team trusts and also they know how the founders and the engineering team work. Many times if you bring a PM from the outside with a completely different process, many times the organ can be rejected by the body.
quotes.context: Explaining when and how to hire your first PM - convert an internal engineer, analyst, or designer

quotes.text: The biggest one I think is, the founder becomes too tactical and disempowers their team. I think the founder thinks they know what customers want. They basically just tell the engineers what to build. And I think that leads to teams that are basically tactically just shaping feature after feature without truly solving problems. That leads to the culture of what is called a feature factory, where product teams basically are very proud of shaping feature after feature without truly knowing how much impact the feature has.
quotes.context: Describing the biggest mistake founders make in product development that creates a feature factory culture

quotes.text: Engineers are by far the most expensive resources in the company. By far. And if you think of it that way, then if you're not caring and feeding and not leveraging this amazing most expensive resource, well, that's a crime. Do I have the bandwidth to sit with them and present the right problems, talk to customers, figure out the right sequencing, the right prioritization of problems to work on? And if you're not able to do that, you've got to have someone who can do that full time.
quotes.context: Making the case for when you need a PM by framing engineers as your most expensive resource

quotes.text: In order to hire, if you want to have a playbook for hiring good leaders or strong leaders for any function, look at best of class companies or companies that are best of class at that function in the similar space. You don't hire the person, the head of marketing at these companies. You hire the person who's reporting to them, the lieutenant. You just literally go through that company and pick out the people.
quotes.context: Sharing his famous hiring playbook - hire lieutenants from best-in-class companies, not the heads

quotes.text: I'm most opposed to director and VP titles. Because those are the titles that lead to the most contention in the company, that lead to the most conflict, that lead to the most disgruntlement. I was meeting with a 25 person company today and that CEO told me, 'I need to hire a general counsel instantly.' Do not give the general counsel title at a 25 person company because the person at a 250 person company is going to be very different. You might still want to retain this person, you just don't want them to be the general counsel.
quotes.context: Explaining his strong opinion on delaying director/VP titles as long as possible at startups

quotes.text: I strongly believe that great founders create new markets themselves, or they pivot. With my check, the biggest mistakes I made early on were sins of omission. I much more care about sins of omission because you can only lose one X your money. But for me, the relationship with the person, I don't want to lose that. It's an optionality for me to invest in not just this company, but in every other company they start. Folks who are unsuccessful the first time around, but then use those learnings to start a company in the same or similar space and then succeed.
quotes.context: Explaining his founder-centric angel investing philosophy and why he regrets passing on investments

quotes.text: We run a very different kind of business. We are focused on efficiency, we're not focused on growth. We don't have any salespeople. We don't have 15 different versions of Basecamp. We're not after enterprise, so we don't have the enormous support costs and enormous support infrastructure required to service customers like that. Nobody can pay us more than 300 bucks. What that allows us to do is to just build one product, do a really nice job, keep it tight, and simple, and clear, and not have the complexity that comes with trying to service and satisfy so many different kinds of companies at different price levels with different price points and different expectations.
quotes.context: Explaining why 37signals has 75 employees while competitors have 1000-3000 employees with similar customer counts

quotes.text: We build products with two people at a time. So every feature we work on in Basecamp, or HEY, or whatever we're building is two people, one programmer, one designer, and they have a maximum of six weeks to deliver the feature that they're working on. Most of them are usually a couple of weeks, but they have a maximum of six weeks. So we don't get stuck in these big huge projects, with meetings with 18 people, and slow decision-making, and indecision, and complexity, and all the things that come with trying to do too many things for too many people.
quotes.context: Describing 37signals' Shape Up methodology for product development

quotes.text: We think that constraints, simplicity, small teams actually are where it's at, and keep us honest, and allow us to do great work for our customer base that we know, small businesses, very tight companies like ours. If you gave me 1,000 people, I wouldn't know what to do with them. We would fall apart. If you gave me 500 people, I wouldn't know what to do with them. We would fall apart. We would be a worse off company with 500 people. I'd be completely lost.
quotes.context: Discussing why staying small is intentional, not just a stepping stone

quotes.text: For me, it's really about, would I want to do this again? If the answer is, 'Yeah, that was enjoyable. I enjoyed that. That was worthwhile. I'm glad I did that. I'd like to do that again,' then it was successful. On the business side of things, we have to be profitable. It's in total, collectively, are we making more money than we spend? That's the only thing we ultimately look at. We don't have financial goals. We don't have OKRs or KPIs. I don't have revenue targets. I don't have growth targets. It's just, at the end, 'Did we make more than we spend? We did. Then the things we did this year were worth it.'
quotes.context: Defining what success means at 37signals - enjoyment over metrics

quotes.text: This is my day job. I want to create the company that I want to work at, and I want to keep doing this job for as long as I can. As long as I'm useful, I'm good at it, I enjoy it, I want to keep doing that. To get in bed with an investment that would say, 'In five years you have to stop doing what you're doing, you're going to get a big paycheck maybe, but you got to stop doing what you're doing because we're going to sell this business,' that just has no appeal to me at all. I'd rather just keep doing the thing that I'm enjoying doing, as long as I can continue to make it work.
quotes.context: Discussing infinite games and why raising venture capital doesn't align with his goals

quotes.text: There's only a few slots for a few companies like that at any one time. Meanwhile, there are hundreds or thousands of slots for other kinds of companies to make it if they don't go for the moon. My interest is optionality. If I could land in 135 different positions and have a sustainable business, that's great. Versus saying there's only one way I'm going to be successful or happy. Those odds aren't really in anyone's favor.
quotes.context: Explaining why the venture-backed unicorn path is not the only path to success

quotes.text: We instead have appetites. And our appetite for any individual feature is no more than six weeks. Essentially that's our budget we're willing to spend. I'm only willing to spend six weeks on any feature. So we have to figure out the simplest, most effective version of that to get that done within six weeks and get it done by two people. Work expands to fill the time available. So for us it's about appetite.
quotes.context: Explaining the Shape Up methodology's concept of appetites vs estimates

quotes.text: Promises are the downfall of every business. Every time we've made a promise to get something out in a certain period of time and we kind of inevitably seem to miss it, it's funny how it's almost like it would've been out in time, but the fact that we'd promised it made it not deliver in time. There's some strange thing that happens when you promise things. So we've learned to not promise anything. The worst promise is by the end of the year. That's the one promise you got to be very careful of, because it's so easy to make. There's nothing easier than promising work later.
quotes.context: Discussing why they don't make promises about delivery dates

quotes.text: I think everything's a judgment call. Yeah, data can play a part. All sorts of things can play a part, but unless you're letting a machine make the decision, that's purely rational. If you're asking a human to make it's a judgment call. They're bringing to bear thousands of things they know and don't know about that influence them about this particular decision. When companies hire executives, what are they looking for? They typically go judgment and experience. They're not like they can read an Excel spreadsheet. They're looking for judgment and experience, which is a very amorphous thing.
quotes.context: Defending gut-driven decision making over data-driven approaches

quotes.text: Give your intuition credit. Give your gut credit. It's absorbed everything. And plus the things that you don't know it absorbed that are valuable. We ask people, what do you think? We might say, what do you know? But we also say, what do you think more often. We talk about how does this feel? How does this screen feel? How does this flow feel? How does this feature feel? Because human beings feel. While we have a logical side to us and a rational side to us, we're primarily feeling creatures.
quotes.context: Encouraging teams to trust their instincts and feelings in product decisions

quotes.text: I didn't have any of this planned out. I didn't decide I wanted to be like this or like that. I just figure out what works and keep doing that until it doesn't. And then, maybe we do something else. We're very much an in-the-now company, making it up as we go. I'm not on a path. I can't see the path. I don't know where I'm going, and I'm perfectly comfortable with that. I think the further out you plan, the less you know about the decisions you're making. And by the time you get there, you're probably going to be wrong, or you're going to want to do something else.
quotes.context: Explaining why they don't do long-term planning and embrace uncertainty

quotes.text: The reason I think it's great for entrepreneurs to start bootstrapping is because they just have more practice making money. They get better and better and better at the fundamental skill you need to have ultimately to run a successful business, which is to make money. Getting good at spending money is not a valuable skill as getting good at making money. You need constraints. When you have just loads of money, you basically have very few constraints. That's what tends to lead to slop.
quotes.context: Explaining why bootstrapping teaches better business fundamentals than venture capital

quotes.text: Management is just about having an outcome. You have a north star, you have a vision, and you're just trying to figure out how to use the resources that you have to get that thing done. Used to be people, but now it's basically models and different models have different strengths. You have to assemble the Avengers so that you can use the right tools for the right purposes.
quotes.context: Explaining how management principles apply directly to working with AI agents and models

quotes.text: Defining the goal and defining the outcome and being really, really crystal clear on what does success look like is the first skill. Different people may have different pictures of what success looks like. How do we get even more specific so that we know without question whether we've hit it or not. This is actually a really, really difficult problem.
quotes.context: Explaining why clarity of outcomes is the most important skill for working with AI and teams

quotes.text: AI allows me to do many of those jobs myself. Now, I'm not going to do them at the PhD or the highest 1%, 10% level, but if I was at the zero or 10th percentile, it can certainly get me even today very quickly up to the 60th, 70th. We need to dissolve the boundaries of these traditional roles. Call ourselves builders. I'd love for us to get to the world where that's the title.
quotes.context: Describing how AI empowers individuals to transcend traditional role boundaries

quotes.text: I don't actually think a lot of the fast-growing companies are using data well at this point. Traditionally things just didn't grow that fast. These companies are totally getting by on just good instincts and good vibes. But what always happens is eventually things stop growing. Growth does not happen forever. And usually when growth stops, that's when you start to see the power of good observability.
quotes.context: Contrarian take on how fast-growing AI companies succeed initially without data infrastructure

quotes.text: What you really want is you want to diagnose with data and treat with design. Data is not a tool that's going to tell you what you should build or what the solution is. But it can tell you if you have a problem and where that problem or opportunity might be. You still need to go back and undergo a very creative process to figure out what's the best way to solve that.
quotes.context: Sharing the perfect framework for balancing data and design that she and her co-founder use

quotes.text: Management is really about this idea of be sturdy while being flexible. I think about this metaphor a lot of the willow tree. The willow tree is a very sturdy tree. It can survive a lot of storms, disasters, et cetera, but it's also very flexible. The branches are very, very flexible, and that's in some ways what allows it to be very sturdy.
quotes.context: Describing the essential balance managers need in times of rapid change and uncertainty

quotes.text: I'm a big believer that every strength is its own weakness, and every weakness is a strength. There's no such thing as you're going to somehow get every dimension to be 100%. We can kind of look at you in infinite dimensions. Each of our profiles is very unique, it's like a fingerprint. None of these dimensions are you entirely. Somebody can give you feedback or you can have room to improve, and that's not who you are.
quotes.context: Introducing the dimensionality framework for self-awareness and managing personal development

quotes.text: Feedback is essentially trying to put your hypotheses and test them against reality. I'm going to ask you for feedback and you're going to give me a gift. It'll be a gift of reflecting something back of what you see that I can't see. Just like if I have a leaf in the back of my head, I can't see that. That is what feedback is. It is essentially reflection back.
quotes.context: Reframing feedback as a gift that helps calibrate our self-perception to reality

quotes.text: It's very difficult for managers to convey purpose if you don't have conviction yourself. Watching your conviction is really important. Sometimes what new managers don't pay attention to enough is what is their true belief. If you don't really believe in what you're doing or you're just parroting the thing that got passed through the organization, it's very hard to be effective or hold that vision and purpose.
quotes.context: Explaining why managers must develop genuine conviction rather than just executing orders

quotes.text: I think if you start thinking adversarially like 'my getting better outcomes has to come at the expense of somebody else losing something,' it's very difficult to be successful. If you say, 'Look, actually, my job is to figure out how to create win-wins,' a lot of things get easier. That has to be a collaboration. If it's not win-win and you could be wrong, that would actually be great information because then maybe we can go back and find a way to make it win-win.
quotes.context: Describing win-win thinking as fundamental to effective management and difficult conversations

quotes.text: I believe that there's infinity in every direction. If my kids say something like going outside is boring or taking a walk is boring, my general response will be, 'Well, it's because you're not seeing the infinity that's in that direction.' Even something really mundane like staring at a blank wall, you can make that actually deeply, deeply interesting if you can find the thing that is deep, and rich, and infinite in that direction.
quotes.context: Sharing her contrarian philosophical worldview that applies to work and life

quotes.text: Emotional regulation is still really, really important. AI makes things so much more comfortable. Technology makes things a lot easier, but you can shortcut a lot of things. How do we actually still learn to sit with what is our true biology that's not changing? True freedom is you can pick the things that are hard and you can feel pride in becoming the thing that you want to be. Don't think about it as a shortcut tool.
quotes.context: Explaining what she teaches her kids about emotional skills in an AI-powered future

quotes.text: There is no question that a lot of companies overhired during the pandemic. I go into some companies and honestly I can't believe all the ridiculous roles that they have, agile coaches and product owners and product ops and business analysts. They're dramatically overpaid for the value they provide. Because it's a project management role.

Too many people in our industry view themselves as a victim of their company, like they're stuck in a feature team and there's nothing they can do about it other than quit. I think that's not true. There is so much they can do.

On a feature team, you're basically given a roadmap of output. Their features are projects. You're being asked to design, build, test, deploy that feature. It is a lot easier to deliver output than it is to deliver outcomes. A product team, instead of being given that roadmap of features, they're given problems to solve.

Strong product companies understand it's all about outcomes. You just don't get points for shipping, you get points for delivering the value. It's about time to money more than time to market. We know how to do time to market. The harder part is time to money.

You need this person who understands the customers and understands the business deeply. That's where the product manager role came from. You need a different set of skills that your engineers and your designers almost never have. Those are very different skillsets.

On a real empowered product team, product manager is a creator, not a facilitator. I always cringe when somebody tells me, oh, my job is to say why? And I'm like, 'Well, what do you do for the rest of the week besides the 10 minutes it takes you to say why?' It's ridiculous.

I was not allowed to take the product manager role until I had visited 30 customers in person, 15 in the US, 15 in Europe. Those 30 customers changed my life because I thought I knew our customers and I really didn't.

You're supposed to be the expert on the data. How is our product being used? How is that usage changing over time? Another big one is you are the person on the team that represents the compliance issues, the sales issues, the marketing issues, the financial cost issues, the monetization issues, go to market in general. This is all the product manager.

Most product management advice you find online, probably 90% of the content out there is from the feature team world or worse. Unless they get really lucky or they happen to have a manager that is guiding them in a good direction, it just propagates.

Product leaders do product strategy. Product teams don't do product strategy. That is the job, is to make these strategic decisions, the focus decisions, the bets you're going to place. Then you give those bets to the teams and you really do give them latitude to figure it out.

Empowerment does not mean you set up this product team and they go decide what to work on. That would just be anarchy. Empowerment means the leaders do their job, come up with the bets, and then the teams are able to figure out the best way to solve those problems.

If you are fundamentally a backlog administrator, good luck protecting that because already people are doing that with AI. That is not a good job prospect. For an empowered product manager, if your responsibility is value and viability, that's the real challenge left.

I looked on the App Store and the number one app in the United States was an app called Sarahah, but the entire app was in Arabic. Like the strongest signal that you could ever have that people want something. The way you should search for product ideas is this concept of latent demand where people are trying to obtain a particular value and going through a very distortive process.
quotes.context: Describing how he discovered the opportunity for tbh by observing an Arabic app being #1 in US

quotes.text: We built 15 apps over four or five years. One took us about a year at first, then our last one took us about two weeks. The most important thing I instruct teams to do is develop a reproducible testing process. That will influence the probability of your success more than anything. It's so unpredictable whether a consumer product idea will work - if you focus on your process for taking many shots at bat, that's what actually reduces the risk.
quotes.context: Explaining the importance of iteration speed and systematic testing over individual ideas

quotes.text: Every tap on a mobile app is a miracle for you as a product developer because users will turn and bounce to their next app very quickly. If you actually sit behind someone and watch them use their phone, they switch between apps at a pretty high frequency. Every tap that you get, every single one is so scarce that you should be optimizing everything.
quotes.context: Describing the shift from web to mobile product thinking and design philosophy

quotes.text: When you're testing something, test the best possible version of what that could be, whether it takes manual work or something that is never going to scale. You want to eliminate all those potentially confounding variables so you can know immediately whether something's working or not. You never want to walk away from an experiment and say 'Well, maybe the execution was bad.'
quotes.context: Explaining why they manually seeded entire schools to test apps properly

quotes.text: When people ask 'What's the benchmark for product-market fit?' this founder Roger Dickey told me: 'If your product's working, you'll know. And if there's any uncertainty, it's not working.' It really is a binary when it comes to consumer products. People are going to be fighting to get into it. Our metric was hourly actives per day, not daily active users.
quotes.context: Describing what true product-market fit feels like for consumer apps

quotes.text: The thing that is hard to really understand for first-time founders that hit breakout success is how draining it is, because everything breaks. Everything you built needs to be substituted almost every three days. Our first customer support system broke after three days. The next one broke seven days later. It is absolute chaos to keep the thing online as it scales up.
quotes.context: Describing the reality of hypergrowth with tbh going viral

quotes.text: For every social app I've built, the number of invitations sent per user drops 20% for every additional year of age from 13 to 18. If you build for adults, expect to acquire every user with ads. If you're targeting older cohorts, you're going to have to raise huge venture capital to finance that user acquisition pipeline.
quotes.context: Explaining why teens are the optimal target for viral social apps

quotes.text: People download apps to make or save money (WhatsApp - free texting), to find a mate (Tinder, Snapchat - find love), or to unplug from reality (Netflix, Fortnite). Putting that in a framing document and the particular nuanced reason why people are going to adopt is difficult when you're presenting to seasoned professionals inside a large company.
quotes.context: Explaining his framework for why people download apps and why big companies struggle with zero-to-one

quotes.text: Large companies take 12 to 24 months to respond to competitive threats. An app starts charting, a PM makes a post, market research does a study, it floats around for months, they put together a framing deck, goes through VP reviews, then development takes 6-12 months. It's hard to present something you have a hunch about - you need market evidence or it's not defensible.
quotes.context: Explaining why incumbents are slow to respond and why copying is the only defensible path inside big companies

quotes.text: As a product manager in a large tech company, there is very little product management that you do. You're actually not as involved in the product as I assumed. You're completely detached from the design process. There's a design vertical org that does all that and they don't really want you working on that. Products live and die in the pixels - that's on you.
quotes.context: Describing the disconnect between PM role and actual product development at Facebook

quotes.text: Put live chat customer support in your app 24 hours a day. It sounds insane - the whole point of tech is you don't need that. But users get this white glove experience, and it's the best vehicle for getting feedback and doing user research because users will literally tell you the problem they're having. Our support rep would paste interesting feedback into Slack and we'd turn it into features.
quotes.context: Sharing tactical advice on eliminating confounding variables during product testing

quotes.text: At the peak of tbh, we were getting 360,000 installs per day. I looked at our numbers and I'm like 'We will be number one in the United States in six days.' Then I looked at our Amazon bill - $120,000. Our bank account said $150,000. I quickly had to put together a funding round. We geofenced the app because we needed to scale our servers and control growth.
quotes.context: Describing the chaos of tbh's viral growth and strategic decision to geofence to control it

quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.text: There is no such thing as a truly viral product. Even Facebook in its heyday had a viral factor of about 0.7. What I mean is, no app has sustained a viral factor of greater than one for any real period of time. The true secret behind virality is word of mouth. It is the virality you can't measure that isn't a mechanic that isn't in a feature. It is when one user spontaneously tells another user about your product.

quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.text: The Switch log. It's born out of the observation that your calendar says what you thought you were going to do, but it's really only your trail of work that describes what you actually did. What if I just did whatever the heck I wanted? Every single time I change task I just Slack DM'd my EA and said, 'TS:,' and then a few words for the task I was doing.

quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.text: I looked at all of the major font families, and honestly none of them was what I would call truly excellent. I was looking for a font that was in and of itself gorgeous, that could convey a message of any kind without overpowering the sentiment, that made reading speed and comprehension really fast, and that made email addresses themselves look great.

quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.text: Email is mission-critical. It's not something where you can simply launch with a half-baked product. When you have mission-critical products like email where you are interfacing with customers, with candidates, with investors, it turns out to really matter. That's why you can't just launch with a half-baked product.

quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.text: You have to pick something. The most well-known brands have stood for one clear thing, they have a clear position. So in order for Superhuman to be memorable, I believed that we needed to occupy a clear position that was unique and which was available and which reinforced our product strategy. That's how speed became our position.

quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.text: At peak we had about 20 people doing manual onboarding. What we found is two things. Number one, the user metrics are excellent for things like engagement, retention, product market fit score, MPS, virality. And number two, in a world where you can easily and quickly raise funding, you can actually use dollars to avoid building a first-time user experience and instead focus all of your engineers on finding product market fit.

quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.text: You can measure product market fit. You can optimize product market fit. You can systematically, even numerically increase product market fit. And you can even have an algorithm write your roadmap for you, and that is a roadmap that is guaranteed to increase product market fit.

quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.text: To get to product market fit, you have to deliberately not act on the feedback of many of your early users. You're listening to people intensely and building what people want. But it can't be all people. The question becomes, how do you listen to them? And then even of what they say, what do you pay attention to and what don't you?

quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.text: We should make business software like we make games, because when we make products like we make games, people find them fun. They tell their friends, they fall in love with them. It's another way of backing into word of mouth. It's not gamification, that doesn't work. Game design works, but game design is not gamification.

quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.text: Make fun toys and then combine those into games. The best games are constructed out of toys. Why? Because then they are fun on both levels, the toy and the game itself. Think about the features of your product. Do those features indulge playful exploration? Are they fun even without a goal? Do they elicit moments of pleasant surprise?

quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.text: SDR - Single Decisive Reason. For important decisions, you should be able to identify one reason that on its own supports the decision. All too often we rely on a collection of weak reasons to justify decisions. Multiple low quality reasons rarely add up to a high quality reason to do something.

If you do a pre-mortem right, you will not have to do an ugly post-mortem. The genius is the initial prompt: imagine this project has failed six months from now. Now work backwards and ask what went wrong. It creates psychological safety for team members to talk about things they're concerned about without being negative.
quotes.context: Introducing the pre-mortem framework with tigers, paper tigers, and elephants

quotes.text: In a pre-mortem, bring up three things: a tiger (a threat that will actually kill us), a paper tiger (a seeming threat others worry about but you're not), and an elephant in the room that nobody is talking about. That shared vocabulary becomes powerful - in future meetings people started saying 'I have this tiger' and it became okay to bring those things up.
quotes.context: Explaining the specific structure of effective pre-mortems

quotes.text: All your tasks are not created equal. There are L tasks (leverage) where you put in effort and get 10X or 100X in return. N tasks (neutral) where you get what you put in. And O tasks (overhead) where you get back less than you put in. Most ambitious people treat each type the same way - and therein lies the problem.
quotes.context: Introducing the LNO framework for prioritizing PM time

quotes.text: The same activity can be an L, N, or O task depending on context. Filing a bug report can be leverage if it's a critical issue requiring detailed documentation, or overhead if it's minor and you're just being thorough. Taking notes can be leverage after a strategic CEO decision, or overhead after a routine sync.
quotes.context: Illustrating how the same activity requires different levels of effort based on strategic importance

quotes.text: Most execution problems that I encounter in high performing environments are actually not execution problems - they are either strategy problems or interpersonal problems or cultural problems. When you put on a bandaid and the bandaid falls off, it's probably not an execution issue.
quotes.context: Explaining why teams stay overwhelmed solving the same problems repeatedly

quotes.text: Two teams misaligned? It looks like an execution problem. But often it's because we don't know what the strategy is. We craft OKRs based on what makes sense, but they're not aligned because we lack clear strategy and priorities. All the review meetings in the world won't fix a strategy problem.
quotes.context: Illustrating how lack of strategy manifests as execution problems

quotes.text: In high leverage roles, stop doing work that simply provides positive ROI. Start focusing on work that minimizes opportunity cost. The problem with ROI mindset is you decrease the denominator by working on quick wins and low-hanging fruit. You fill your plate with quick wins and miss the upside by not focusing on optimal things.
quotes.context: Explaining the opportunity cost framework learned from observing Patrick Collison at Stripe

quotes.text: Opportunity cost is the value of the optimal option minus the value of the chosen option. When we reprogram ourselves to think in terms of opportunity cost, we're no longer thinking 'Is this a good use of my time?' Instead: 'Is this the best use of my time?' It's a subtle but profound shift.
quotes.context: Contrasting opportunity cost thinking with traditional ROI thinking

quotes.text: I learned from Google's 70-20-10: during planning, give teams allocation guidance. 60% on incrementals (high ROI features), 30% on big new initiatives (can't be five initiatives, probably one or two), 10% on stability and infrastructure. This gives people space to pursue the right things instead of filling everything with quick wins.
quotes.context: Sharing tactical guidance on portfolio allocation to enable opportunity cost thinking

quotes.text: High agency is finding a way to get what you want without waiting for conditions to be perfect or blaming circumstances. The PMs who surprised me in positive ways - exceeded their capabilities on paper - all had high agency: strong ownership, creative execution through challenges, and high resilience.
quotes.context: Describing the trait that differentiates high-impact PMs from those with unrealized potential

quotes.text: At Google I learned the power of thinking really big. There was this unwritten rule: if it's not going to generate more than $100 million in revenue, it's not worth talking about. They would regularly not pursue $100 million opportunities because they had access to billion dollar ones. That habit to ask 'can we make it 10X bigger?' got ingrained.
quotes.context: Describing Google's culture of thinking big and pursuing only massive opportunities

quotes.text: Jack Dorsey would just listen a lot more than you'd expect the CEO to listen. Then he would ask one vital question. We discussed a potential acquisition - went through all the intellectual arguments, strategic arguments, metrics arguments. Jack asked: 'How does this make our users love Twitter more?' Simple question. We never really talked about that. I didn't have a good answer.
quotes.context: Describing Jack Dorsey's leadership style and ability to ask penetrating questions

quotes.text: We're on these narrow sidewalks in Vancouver when it starts raining. Most people with umbrellas wouldn't move them out of the way - the pokey bits are at eye level. Only one-third would tilt their umbrella. We said your failure to really exercise this courtesy and be empathic about other people's experience is an advantage that you can create.
quotes.context: The umbrella tilt story that became a core Slack value about product craftsmanship and empathy

quotes.text: Utility curves: first bit of effort produces no value, then there's a magic threshold where it produces enormous value, then continued investment doesn't pay off. We would investigate whether we were on the first shallow part of the curve, the second shallow part, or just coming up to it. This helped us decide whether something was worth it.
quotes.context: Explaining the utility curve S-curve framework for product investment decisions

quotes.text: It became an assumption that you should always be trying to remove friction. But the challenge is really comprehension. If your software stops me and asks me to make a decision and I don't really understand it, you make me feel stupid. Instead of reducing clicks or taps, focus on how can I make this simple? How do I prevent people from having to think?
quotes.context: Explaining why comprehension matters more than reducing friction or clicks

quotes.text: Have you exhausted the possibilities? Creating the distance so that you can make an intellectual rational decision rather than an emotional decision is essential. The reason I say you have to be coldly rational is because pivoting is fucking humiliating. You convinced so many people - investors, employees, press, users - and now you're admitting 'I was wrong. This didn't work.'
quotes.context: Explaining the emotional difficulty of pivoting after Glitch  Slack and Flickr pivots

quotes.text: This is 2014, the year Slack launched. MIT Technology Review asked if we were working to improve Slack. I said, 'I feel like what we have right now is just a giant piece of shit. It's terrible and we should be humiliated that we offer this to the public.' If you can't see almost limitless opportunities to improve, you shouldn't be designing the product.
quotes.context: Expressing divine discontent and high standards for Slack even after launch

quotes.text: We invented the magic link experience. Typing your password on your phone if you have any minimal threshold of password hygiene is a terrible experience. Capital H, lowercase Q, six, caret, period. So let's just have them enter email address, send them a link, and it automatically opens the app and authenticates them.
quotes.context: Describing Slack's early UX innovation that became an industry standard

quotes.text: We came up with the shouty rooster. When you @everyone, a little rooster pops up with sound waves and says 'This is going to cause a notification for 147 people in eight different time zones. Are you sure?' That worked amazingly - it dropped off the abuse. It also taught people how the product worked because they probably didn't think about the cost.
quotes.context: Example of delightful UX that shapes behavior and prevents spam

quotes.text: In the long run, the measure of our success will be the amount of value that we create for customers. You can put effort into demonstrating that you have created this value, but there's no substitute for actually having created it. I made everyone in the company repeat this as a chant at all hands.
quotes.context: The core philosophy that guided Slack's product development

quotes.text: The default advice for anyone is persevere - 'hang in there.' But I think you have to be coldly rational. Slack had an enormous advantage: we were working on it for several years without explicitly working on it, only doing features that were so irritating we couldn't stand it anymore. When I had exhausted every non-ridiculous long shot idea to make Glitch commercially successful, I decided to abandon it.
quotes.context: Explaining when to pivot vs persevere using the Glitch  Slack example

quotes.text: Don't Make Me Think. For two reasons: it's expensive to make a decision - you literally burn glucose, there's cognitive cost. But also there's an emotional aspect: if your software stops me and asks me to make a decision I don't understand, you make me feel stupid. Most people feel 'I'm dumb' not 'the software is stupid.' They associate that bad feeling with the product forever.
quotes.context: Expanding on the Don't Make Me Think mantra with biological and emotional reasoning

quotes.text: Google Calendar's time zone picker presents all time zones in alphabetical order. When I type E-A-S-T, first one is Eastern Australia, New South Wales. It's bananas how bad it is - used by hundreds of millions, presumably every Google employee. No one's going to switch from Outlook because the time zone picker is good, but there's real value in delighting customers. That emotional connection makes them recommend it or advocate for it when they switch companies.
quotes.context: Using Google Calendar as example of neglecting craft and its impact on emotional connection

quotes.text: When we shut down Glitch, there were people who loved it and would spend all their free time on it. That was their community and it just disappeared. People lost jobs, people who moved families to different cities. Pivots aren't something I take lightly. It's very different to be like 'there's three of us and we pivoted to a different app.' If you're six months in, you're still messing around. That doesn't even really count.
quotes.context: Reflecting on the painful human cost of pivoting from Glitch to Slack
